title: Is Dark Chocolate Healthy? See How It Can Be!
body:
Is dark chocolate healthy? While we wouldn't exactly call it a superfood, dark chocolate does have some remarkable health benefits, making it a good choice for dessert. It is loaded with vitamins, flavonols, and antioxidants, and as we outline below, dark chocolate has plenty of other advantages. Just to be clear: We're not talking about the processed, sugar-laden candy bars you'll find in the supermarket checkout aisle. We mean high-quality dark chocolate with at least 60 percent cocoa content. What makes dark chocolate healthy? Check out some of its benefits:

  1. Dark chocolate is a mood-booster. Dark chocolate is full of compounds that can help prevent depression, such as anandamide, which is structurally similar to THC but much milder. Anandamide can give you a good mood and energy lift, without the potential health concerns that come with other stimulating substances. Chocolate also contains phenylethylamine, which converts to mood lifting and stabilizing serotonin in the body.
  2. Dark chocolate is loaded with antioxidants, and provides excellent free-radical protection. There are more polyphenols and flavonoids present in dark chocolate than in either tea or wine. These help neutralize free radicals, and shield the body from their potential damage.
  3. Dark chocolate can lower blood pressure. The flavonols in dark chocolate can stimulate the endothelium (the lining of arteries) to produce nitric oxide, which then signals the arteries to relax. This lowers resistance to blood flow, thereby lowering blood pressure.
  4. Dark chocolate may help prevent cancer. The rich supply of flavonoids in dark chocolate may account for its potential cancer-fighting properties. While studies are still emerging, they suggest that chocolate’s antioxidant properties possibly protect against free radical cellular damage that leads to cancer formation.
  5. Flavonols favorably impact heart health. Eating flavonoid-rich dark chocolate is good for your heart. A study published in the International Journal of Cardiology reports that dark chocolate intake considerably improved heart circulation in healthy adults. The compounds in dark chocolate are also significantly protective against the oxidation of LDL, which causes less cholesterol to lodge in the arteries over time.
  6. Dark chocolate may protect your skin against the sun. Flavonols can protect against sun damage, and also improve blood flow to the skin.
  7. Dark chocolate is amazing brain food. One study showed that five days of high-flavonol dark cocoa consumption improved blood flow to the brain in healthy volunteers. Another study reports that dark chocolate consumption improved cognitive and verbal function in elderly adults with mental impairment.

While fresh fruit, vegetables, and tea are known as fantastic sources of antioxidants (and you should definitely consume lots of them), research shows that the cocoa bean is an even more potent source. It features one of the highest concentrations of nutrients and antioxidants of any food. That makes dark chocolate healthy, as long as you enjoy it in moderation. Your best bet is to buy 100 percent cocoa or raw cacao powder, and add it to your smoothies, whole grain cereals, or low-sugar homemade dishes. If you go with bars that are at least 60 to 70 percent cocoa, one to three squares per day is all you need to enjoy the benefits.

title: This Fantastic Protein Shake Will Energize You
body:
Your standard protein shake can be chalky, flavorless, and the last thing you feel like drinking... no matter how good it may be for you. That's why we've created an energizing protein shake that is not just nutritious, but also delicious. Adding espresso to the mix makes this protein shake the perfect morning or pre-workout drink to boost your energy and get you vital nutrients. As we've emphasized in the past, caffeine is no substitute for the energy you get from a healthy lifestyle. But moderate consumption of espresso can benefit your health in a number of ways. It's been shown to improve long-term memory, maintain dopamine levels, and facilitate focus. We recommend drinking the shake about one hour before exercising. Just remember: You can have too much of a good thing, and consuming excessive caffeine can lead to anxiety, sleeplessness, and other negative consequences. Try not to exceed two cups per day. The more important component in this shake is the protein. Getting enough protein can be challenging during busy days, especially since most people rely on animal protein, which can involve a lot more preparation. By adding organic protein powder to a morning or afternoon meal, you'll increase satiety and help ensure that your body gets what it needs. Specifically, our body needs protein to produce hormones, repair tissues, and maintain healthy bones and metabolic function. We recommend choosing an organic variety sourced from pea, grass-fed whey, hemp, or brown rice. Watch for added sugars and other ingredients you don't recognize. Chia literally means "strength," and was used as an energy booster in ancient Aztec society. Adding chia seeds to this smoothie is the perfect way to boost its nutrient content. Chia seeds expand and form a gel-like substance in the stomach, helping to satiate and prevent overeating. They also have a concentration of omega-3 fatty acids, antioxidants, and fiber. Protein Shake Ingredients:
  • 1 cup unsweetened almond milk
  • 1 frozen banana
  • 1 shot of espresso
  • 1 tablespoon cacao
  • 1 serving chocolate protein powder
  • 1 tablespoon chia seeds
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla
  • handful of ice
Protein Shake Preparation: Step 1: Add all ingredients to a high-speed blender Step 2: Blend on high until completely smooth. Serve immediately.

title: Dr. Tania Elliott, EHE's Chief Medical Officer, Gives Advice on "The Rachael Ray Show" (VIDEO)
body: EHE's Chief Medical Officer, Dr. Tania Elliott, appeared on "The Rachael Ray Show" on Wednesday. Dr. Elliott helped clear up some common misconceptions about the use of essential oils. For one thing, don't ingest them. They're not the same as edible extracts! Also important: If you're applying the oils topically, dilute them first. title: You Can Make This Recipe to Get Amazing Matcha Tea Benefits
body: Matcha tea benefits your health in a variety of ways. Since you consume the green tea leaf whole when using matcha, all of the tea's antioxidant levels are multiplied. Antioxidants help fight inflammation, protect against ultraviolet (UV) exposure and heal existing damage, slows premature aging, and boost energy. According to oxygen radical absorbance capacity (ORAC), matcha ranks highest in the number of antioxidants, boasting five times the level of other plant-based foods. Matcha is also a great substitute for coffee, since the antioxidant levels help slow the absorption of caffeine into our system. Many people notice steady energy and intense focus when they drink matcha, as opposed to the high and subsequent crash they may experience with other caffeine sources. Our matcha latte recipe harnesses these great matcha tea benefits. We’ve included collagen powder to add even more healing powers to the matcha base. Collagen powder helps heal our intestinal lining, has been shown to decrease wrinkles and cellulite, and improves joint pain. About  70 percent of our skin is collagen, which is what gives our skin its natural elasticity. Since our collagen production naturally decreases as we age, increasing our consumption of vitamin C (which helps manufacture collagen) and supplements can help keep our skin smooth and glowing. Matcha tea benefits are plentiful, and this latte is a delicious delivery system! Ingredients 1/2 teaspoon matcha powder 1/4 cup hot water (175 degrees F) 1 cup almond milk 1 tablespoon collagen powder 1 teaspoon honey 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla Pinch sea salt Directions Step 1: Measure matcha into a small bowl or mug. pour over hot water (be sure not to heat too high, or you will burn the matcha powder and your drink will taste bitter). Step 2: Use a matcha whisk or hand blender to fully dissolve powder into the liquid, until no clumps remain. Step 3: Add collagen powder, honey, vanilla, and salt. Mix until they dissolve. Step 4: Heat almond milk, using a frother if you like your lattes foamy. Step 5: Pour almond milk over mixture and enjoy a latte brimming with matcha tea benefits!

title: How to Be Great at Meal Prep Sunday
body:
Meal Prep Sunday is just what it sounds like: planning and preparing a series of meals all at once. It's not a new idea, but it's recently become a fixation among people who seek good nutrition despite tight budgets and busy schedules. Not only is it an efficient (and cost-effective!) way to cook, but it lends itself to healthy eating. Food "prep" can mean a variety of things — from fully preparing each meal so it's ready to eat, to simply washing and chopping ingredients in order to streamline the cooking process. The ultimate goal on Meal Prep Sunday is to invest effort early to ensure thoughtful, healthy eating later. When you prepare food for the week ahead, it's easier to preserve good eating habits even after the chaos of the week begins. We have a few general guidelines for becoming a Meal Prep Sunday master, as well as an incredibly easy and delicious mini frittata recipe for healthy grab-and-go breakfasts you can make ahead of a week's worth of hectic mornings. Enjoy! Tip #1: The Slow Cooker Is Your Meal Prep Sunday Friend The slow cooker is the absolute perfect tool for food prep and easy dinners throughout the week. There are a few ways you can use it. The first is to find one recipe you love (like a soup or chili), press start on Sunday, and by Monday morning you'll have five lunches magically ready to go. If you don't need a ton of variety over the course of your week, this is a great way to get all of your lunches done at once. If variety is important, we recommend creating "slow cooker packs" for dinner. Each Sunday, choose three to five slow cooker recipes that sound good to you. Simply put all of the ingredients into large freezer bags, mark the meal and the date you want it, and store in the fridge. Each morning, simply grab a bag, pour it into the slow cooker, and press start. By the time you're home from work, dinner is served! The great thing with these meal packs is that you can make a dozen or more at a time. Tip #2: Make One-Pan Dinners Happen If your cooking style is more spontaneous, there's no need to make full meals all at once. Simply cleaning and chopping your herbs, vegetables, and fruits can make the week ahead a breeze. Cleaning meat and prepping your seasoning ahead of time only add to the convenience. We also recommend cooking grains like quinoa and rice, or steaming starchy vegetables like sweet potatoes, in large quantities before the week begins. One-pan dinners are the perfect way to utilize this type of prep. Since veggies will already be chopped and meats already marinated, simply spread them on a sheet pan with avocado or olive oil, and bake at 400 degrees for 20-30 minutes, depending on the specific ingredients you're using. Because your grains will already be cooked as well, simply scoop a portion onto everyone's plate and heat. Voila! Another option is to create "stir fry bags" out of your chopped veggies and meats. Just pour them into a wok for a quick, no-mess dinner. Tip #3: Try to Get Your Vegetables at Lunch Creating a week's worth of salads each Sunday is an excellent way to integrate a larger (and more diverse) set of vegetables and fruits into your diet. Every plant comes with its own unique composition of micronutrients; "eating the rainbow" throughout the week will help you cover your nutrient bases. Choose 6-12 varieties each week (or more!). On Sunday, pick a few varieties for each salad container and build interesting combinations as your base. Next, top each container with a different fat, like raw nuts or avocado. Last, choose a protein like chickpeas, quinoa, chicken, or hard boiled eggs to make your salads satiating. Half of a lemon and a tablespoon of olive oil is the perfect dressing. You can keep oil at work, or bring in mini containers to dress right before you eat so your salad doesn't get soggy. Tip #4: Meal Prep Sunday Supercharges Breakfast   We've all heard it before: Breakfast is the most important meal of the day. But you may find it is also the most challenging meal to find time to prepare, given how rushed we tend to be before work or school. We recommend getting 15-20 grams of protein within two hours of waking up to kick start your metabolism. One favorite Meal Prep Sunday option for breakfast is a smoothie pack. For smoothie packs, combine greens, fruit, and booster foods like chia or flax seeds in bags; then, store them in the freezer. Each morning, simply pour the contents into a blender with protein powder and your preferred liquid. Breakfast is served. Meal Prep Sunday Recipe for Mini Frittatas Another great option is this recipe! Any vegetables and meats can be substituted here, so feel free to create your own perfect combination. Ingredients:
  • 5 eggs
  • 1 1/2 cups egg whites
  • 1 1/2 cup spinach
  • 3/4 cup cherry tomatoes
  • 1/4 red onion
  • small handful of basil
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • 1/2 cup sharp cheddar cheese (optional)
Step 1: Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Blend or whisk whole eggs, egg whites, salt, and pepper. Step 2: Grease muffin tins. Slice onions and basil. Cut tomatoes in half. Wash and dry spinach. Evenly distribute vegetables in 12 muffin tins. Step 3: Pour egg mixture over vegetables, until 3/4 full. Top with cheese (if using). Step 4: Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until lightly browned and cooked through. Step 5: Muffins can be stored in the fridge and reheated in a toaster oven throughout the week for a quick grab-and-go option in the morning. So make them a part of your next (or first) Meal Prep Sunday!

title: Make These Fantastic and Easy Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies
body: Giving up sugar can leave us feeling deprived and as though we'll never eat dessert again. But this recipe for sugar-free peanut butter cookies is proof that cutting out most sugar doesn't mean needing to give up treats altogether! These cookies taste great, and you'll feel like you're indulging... but without wrecking havoc on your system. Processed sugar adds unnecessary calories to your diet without giving you the nutrients you need. The body is not particularly interested in calories themselves. Its primary focus is getting specific nutrients. Everything from fluid balance, nerve function, metabolism, energy production, bone structure, and proper digestion all require specific macronutrients and micronutrients. When we fill our diet with nutritionally empty calories — such as sugar, processed wheat, and poor quality dairy — our body continues to give us hunger signals, since it hasn't received what it needs. This can lead to overeating and weight gain over time. Fructose, when consumed through fruit, where the micronutrients and fiber slow the release of sugar into the bloodstream, isn't something to fear. However, when consumed in excess in the form of processed and packaged sugars, soda, and desserts, it will be converted into glycogen and stored by the liver. For individuals who chronically overeat these foods, the liver becomes too full of glycogen and begin to turn fructose into fat. This can lead to a condition called fatty liver and, if left untreated, eventually liver disease. Organic stevia has been used for centuries. It is a plant with naturally sweet leaves. While the stevia plant can be grown and used in its natural form, more conveniently it has also been turned into a powder which can be found in most grocery stores. Be sure to choose 100% organic stevia to avoid other additives and chemicals some brands use in their formulas. Since it does not affect the blood sugar, stevia can be a great option for preventing metabolic syndrome, keeping mood and energy stable, and creating steady hunger levels. Stevia also contains antioxidant properties, which helps fight inflammation in the body (whereas regular sugar actually causes inflammation in the body). Ingredients for Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies: 1.5 cups peanut butter 3 tablespoons cacao 2 eggs 1/4 cup chopped peanuts 1 teaspoon stevia powder* 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon *If you prefer the taste of sugar over stevia, you can replace with 1/2 cup of coconut palm sugar. How to Make Sugar-Free Peanut Butter Cookies: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Add all ingredients to an electric mixer and mix on high until fully combined. Step 2: Scoop dough out in heaping tablespoons, and roll into smooth balls. Step 3: Lay balls onto parchment lined baking sheet. Use a fork to smash dough flat (the cookies will not spread while baking). Step 4: Bake for 7-10 minutes depending on desired crispiness. Enjoy your sugar-free peanut butter cookies!

title: Make These Amazing and Healthy Holiday Cocktails
body:
The holidays are a time to eat, drink, and be merry. But that doesn't mean you have to sacrifice all of the healthy habits you're trying to keep! Holiday cocktails can be healthy (or, at least, healthier) than you might expect, as long as you give some thought to the ingredients ahead of time. We've come up with a few modified recipes for holiday cocktails (including one that's easily turned into an alcohol-free "mocktail"), each of which offers some nice health benefits along with the usual seasonal cheer. The recipes below serve eight delicious, healthy holiday cocktails apiece unless otherwise indicated. And, of course, please drink responsibly!

Pomegranate Sparkler

Want to add some lush color to your cocktail offerings? How about some critical nutrients and powerful preventive health benefits? Pomegranate juice has anti-inflammatory properties, comes packed with antioxidants, and contains polyphenols shown to counteract prostate and breast cancers. The fruit is also good for your heart, with research showing that it can help lower blood pressure and reduce plaque in the carotid artery. (How's that for a holiday gift?) Pomegranate juice is also a good source of vitamins C and E, as well as potassium. That all makes these sparkling holiday cocktails an exciting option for you and your loved ones. Ingredients: eight ounces of pomegranate juice (be sure to get 100% juice with no added sugar) four ounces of fruit liqueur (such as Curacao or Grand Marnier) four teaspoons of lime juice (or lime wedges) four teaspoons of pomegranate seeds several sprigs of mint (if so desired) sparkling wine (chilled) Preparation: Sprinkle pomegranate seeds into Champagne flutes, followed by the pomegranate juice and your chosen liqueur. Add lime and then pour the chilled sparkling wine. Top off with mint and enjoy!

Dairy-Free Eggnog

  Eggnog is among the most polarizing holiday drinks, so even if it's not your favorite, there's a good chance someone at your party may ask, "Hey, where's the nog?" One major problem with traditional eggnog in modern times? Lots of people are going off dairy. Fortunately, we have a solution. This dairy-free eggnog recipe is just as delicious as the standard version, but substitutes almond milk and coconut milk for the cow milk your guests may be trying to avoid. And it couldn't be any simpler to make! Ingredients: four cups of coconut milk four cups of almond milk eight large egg yolks one cup of pure maple syrup two teaspoons of ground cinnamon two teaspoons of nutmeg two teaspoons of pure vanilla extract Preparation: Combine all ingredients (except nutmeg) in a blender. Blend for approximately two minutes. Egg yolks should be fully processed. Chill in refrigerator until ready to serve, then pour and top with nutmeg.

Ginger Cider Hot Toddy

It's hard to find anything more comforting on a chilly winter's night than this classic drink, whether you include alcohol or not! In fact, one of the best things about a hot toddy is that it can be tailored for almost any taste — since the tea and cider varieties are up to you — and still be great. This version includes ginger, which aids digestion, boosts immune function, and has been shown to have a positive impact on everything from cholesterol to respiration to reducing nausea. If you make yours with green tea, you'll also get the benefit of polyphenols. Makes one mug. Ingredients: two cups of warm apple cider one tea bag one tablespoon of honey 1/8 teaspoon of ginger one lemon one cinnamon stick one shot of your preferred whiskey (optional) Preparation: Heat mug of cider and steep tea bag for five minutes. Mix in ginger and honey. Add booze. Stir with cinnamon stick. Top with slice of lemon. Enjoy!

White Sangria

This festive, fruit-filled crowdpleaser features the many health benefits of apples (they help in the fight against cardiovascular disease, contain antioxidants and soluble fiber), citrus (vitamin C, flavonoids, potassium), and the often overlooked nutritional advantages of white wine. Ingredients: two bottles of white wine two apples two cups of preferred citrus fruit one cup of grapes one cup of frozen tropical fruit (like mango) Preparation: This one is especially easy. Just cut up the fruit, add to a pitcher of white wine, refrigerate overnight, and serve!

title: Learn How to Make Gluten-Free Banana Bread
body:
Banana bread is classic comfort food (especially when you have overripe bananas you don't want to waste). Gluten-free banana bread is just as tasty, while also letting people on low- or no-gluten diets enjoy the treat. And the version we make is even healthier, since we've removed the processed sugar and refined ingredients included in traditional recipes. The result is a wholesome gluten-free banana bread you'll love!

Bananas are the perfect base for baked goods, since they keep bread moist without needing excessive amounts of oil or butter. They also contain many important nutrients. Additionally, they're full of fiber, which helps slow the digestion of sugar into the bloodstream. One banana also contains more than a third of our daily vitamin B6 requirement. B vitamins are crucial for metabolism, energy, a well-functioning nervous system, and skin health. B6, specifically, improves brain function, facilitates the manufacturing of hemoglobin, and is good for healthy immune function. It also helps to maintain a positive mood, since it factors in the production of serotonin. 

For fat, we've chosen ghee (with the option of using coconut oil if you're vegan). Ghee is a form of clarified butter — meaning the milk proteins are removed, but the vitamins stay intact (unlike commercially produced butter). Ghee is full of Omega-3 and Omega-9 fatty acids; it's also one of the best sources of conjugated linoleic acid, which has anti-cancer properties. Since the milk proteins are removed from ghee, many individuals with dairy sensitivities find that they can tolerate it well, making it the perfect substitute for our gluten-free banana bread recipe! 

We've created a slight twist by adding raw cacao to the mix. This gives our gluten-free banana bread a rich chocolate flavor, so you'll feel like you're eating dessert! The antioxidant levels in cacao are incredibly high — 40 times higher than blueberries, in fact. It's also rich in iron, making it an excellent dietary addition for vegans and vegetarians who don't consume iron-rich animal products. You'll find more calcium in cacao than in dairy milk, which is good for preventing osteoporosis and helpful for growing children and teens. And cacao also has calming properties, since it's so rich in magnesium, which is often touted as the "relaxation mineral" since it helps steady nerves, reduces anxiety, and may help people with insomnia. 

Ingredients:

4 very ripe bananas 1/2 cup ghee or coconut oil 1.5 teaspoons baking soda 1/3 teaspoon salt 1/2 cup coconut palm sugar or maple syrup 1 egg 1.25 teaspoons vanilla 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 1 1/2 cups gluten-free flour 1/4 cup raw, unsweetened cacao powder Optional: cacao nibs for topping

Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Mash bananas with a fork, then cream together with the ghee, coconut palm sugar, egg, and vanilla. 

Step 2: In a separate bowl, thoroughly combine flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, and cacao powder.

Step 3: Add dry ingredients slowly to wet ingredients. Fold together until fully combined. 

Step 4: Line a 9x5 loaf pan with parchment paper and lightly grease. Pour in batter and optionally top with cacao nibs. Bake for 40-50 minutes, or until a toothpick comes out clean when pierced into bread. 

Step 5: Enjoy your gluten-free banana bread!

title: Why You Need to Practice Mindful Eating
body:
How to Practice Mindful Eating In a broad sense, mindfulness is simply taking notice of your thoughts, behaviors, and habits. Mindful eating means we take our time to eat, observe when we are hungry and when we feel full, and pay attention to what we eat and where it comes from. Mindful eating means we understand that how we eat is an important consideration, just like what we eat. Here are five ways to establish mindful eating habits:
  1. Listen to your body. In our frenetically paced culture, we often lose track of the fundamentals of eating. Pay attention to your physical hunger signals, and observe when your body feels full. Often, we eat too rapidly and ignore when our bodies say it's time to stop. Slowing down is the best way to ensure our bodies have the chance to express nutritional needs, and it also makes eating more enjoyable.
  2. Turn off the phone and TV. Make your personal and family meals as distraction-free as possible. Try to eat at the same established times each day. Make space for some quiet time at the dinner table. Keep conversation as gentle, joyful, and stress-free as you can. If you do decide to have movie nights with dinner in front of the TV, do so consciously, and perhaps only on weekends.
  3. Savor your food. Pay attention to all the things you love about your meal — the textures, colors, and flavors. Allow yourself to focus t0tally on the experience. Slow down, breathe, and give yourself the time to fully enjoy your food. Not only will your pleasure in eating increase, you will digest and assimilate your meal better
  4. Know your food and where it comes from. Choose the highest quality fresh and natural foods you can afford. Engage yourself in the meal-making process. Do you know who grew your food and where it originated? Maybe you can find a local market or bakery where you interact with the people who supply your ingredients. A simple appreciation for the food you eat can increase your enjoyment exponentially. And the more mindful you are about the quality of foods you and your family eat (and where they come from), the more likely you are to make better choices.
  5. Balance food as comfort with nutritional needs. Sometimes we eat to fulfill emotional needs, rather than considering the quality or nutritional value of our meal. Healthy, natural foods can be prepared in ways that provide plenty of enjoyment and comfort without sacrificing nutrition. Mindful eating leads you to eat what you want, but in a higher quality and cleaner way. The more fresh foods you eat, the better they will taste to you.
With mindful eating, we train ourselves to pay closer attention to our bodies' real needs. The process of cooking and eating should be a pleasure — but it also needs to be nourishing. The more deliberate and conscious we are, the more we get out of it.

title: This Gluten-Free Stuffing Is Perfect for Thanksgiving
body: Gluten-free stuffing is becoming more mainstream as more people give up gluten. Some individuals (like those with celiac disease) can get very sick if they eat it. Other people may have more mild intolerances or sensitivities to gluten. Others go gluten-free because they find it keeps their skin more clear, improves digestion, gives them more energy, and is otherwise a positive for their health. What Exactly Is Gluten? Gluten refers to the glutenin and gliadin proteins found in any wheat, rye, or barley products. It's responsible for the sticky texture of wheat-based dough, and gives bread the chewy texture that we all love. People with celiac disease can't process gluten, which activates their immune response. This leads the body to attack not only the gluten, but also the digestive system, causing horrible stomach cramping and longer-term consequences. Some without celiac disease experience intolerance on a milder scale, with bloating, stomach aches, digestion issues, breakouts, mood decline, and energy slumps. If you suspect you have an intolerance to gluten, doing an elimination diet (removing all allergins for 2-3 weeks, then slowly adding suspected allergins one at a time) can be helpful in determining your personal response to gluten and other foods like dairy. Even if your body does tolerate gluten, try to choose organic, whole grain products with no added sugar. Preferably, wheat products are sprouted, which makes the nutrients found in grains more accessible to the human body. The Gluten-Free Stuffing Solution If you do decide to go gluten-free, it can be challenging to miss out on foods you once loved. Especially around the holidays, when baked goods and classic holiday recipes are abundant, it's easy to feel like something's lacking. We've created this gluten-free stuffing recipe to help you enjoy the full Thanksgiving spread. Not only is this recipe full of flavor, but it comes with a variety of health benefits. We've included antioxidant-rich produce like carrots, onions, apples, and celery. We've also chosen wholesome fats like ghee and olive oil, and plenty of herbs to add both flavor and nutrients. Ingredients: 1.5 loaves gluten-free bread (preferably a sourdough variety like Udi's) 4 fresh sage leaves 1 teaspoon dried oregano 2 cups bone broth or turkey broth* 3-4 large carrots, sliced 1 apple, chopped 2 celery stock, sliced 1 small yellow onion, chopped 3-4 cloves garlic, minced 2 eggs 1/2 cup ghee* 1/4 cup olive oil salt and pepper to taste *To make this recipe vegan, use vegetable broth and replace ghee with olive oil Step 1: Preheat oven to 225. Grease a casserole dish. Cut bread into large bite-size pieces. Spread bread cubes onto a baking sheet. Bake for 45 minutes, to dry out bread. Step 2: While bread bakes, cut vegetables. Heat ghee and olive oil over medium, cook onion for three minutes. Add carrots and celery and cook for another for five minutes. Next add apple, garlic, herbs, and salt and pepper, then cook for an additional three minutes. Set aside. Step 3: Preheat oven to 325 degrees. In a large bowl, whisk eggs and broth together. Toss in bread. Let the bread sit in the egg-broth mixture, tossing every five minutes until the mixture has fully soaked all of the bread (this is important to avoid dry stuffing). Once the bread is soaked, toss with vegetables and pour into a casserole dish. Step 4: Cover stuffing and bake for 30 minutes. Remove cover and bake for an additional 10-15 minutes, or until top is golden brown. Now it's time to serve your gluten-free stuffing!

title: Make This Wonderful and Healthy Pumpkin Pie
body: Making a healthy pumpkin pie can be tricky. While pumpkin on its own has great nutritional value, the traditional Thanksgiving dessert we know is filled with sugar, dairy, and processed wheat — a far cry from clean eating. This year, we’ve switched to a gluten-free crust, clean sugars, and organic pumpkin for a version that’s just as tasty but much healthier. We’ve chosen a store-bought crust to make preparation of this healthy pumpkin pie simpler, although making your own crust is, of course, always an option. Using a gluten-free or whole grain crust helps ensure that the dessert will be free from refined starches that lead to a spike in blood sugar. It's preferable to pick an option with fiber, which will slow the absorption of sugar into the blood while also aiding digestion. Fiber promotes a feeling of fullness and helps to prevent overeating. Additionally, it helps feed good gut bacteria, improves immunity, and removes excess hormones like estrogen. We’ve given you the option to use canned pumpkin for this pie; if possible, choose organic, pure pumpkin. It makes the dessert more dense in nutrients. You’ll see other canned options called something like “pumpkin pie filling,” so be sure to check that pumpkin is the only listed ingredient. In addition to the fiber found in a properly chosen crust, one can of pumpkin adds seven grams of fiber. Pumpkin, like most brightly-colored orange, yellow, and red produce, is rich in beta-carotene, a nutrient which the body converts to Vitamin A. Vitamin A is important for eye health, reproductive function, and immunity. If you’ve chosen a fresh pumpkin, be sure to save the seeds. They are rich in potassium, magnesium, and zinc. They have also been shown to contain properties that fight off certain chronic diseases like cancer. The fat found in coconut milk is useful in absorbing nutrients like Vitamin A. Vitamins A, D, E, and K are all fat soluble, meaning they require fat in order for the body to absorb and utilize them. Pairing foods containing these nutrients with fats found in coconut, avocado, olive oil, and raw nuts (to name a few), is important. It’s also a reason to avoid diets extremely low in fat. They can result in vitamin deficiencies and a slew of other ailments in the body. So... let's make healthy pumpkin pie! Ingredients: Filling: 2 1/2 cups pumpkin puree 1/2 cup full-fat coconut milk 1/2 cup maple syrup 1 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice 1 1/2 tsp pure vanilla extract 1/2 tsp salt 1 egg 1 tablespoon ground flax seeds Crust: 1 gluten-free or whole grain crust Topping: 1 can full-fat coconut milk, stored in the fridge overnight 1 teaspoon vanilla Step 1: Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Lay out your dough over a pie plate and gently press dough to mold into the plate. Optionally, create a pattern at the edges with your fingers or a fork. Step 2: Blend all pumpkin pie ingredients together in a high-speed blender. Pour puree into crust. Lightly smooth pumpkin and tap on counter to remove any air bubbles. Bake 40-50 minutes until lightly browned and still jiggly in the middle. Step 3: Let pie cool to room temperature, then cover and store in the fridge for at least 4 hours (preferably overnight). If using coconut whip, place a can of full-fat coconut milk in the fridge with pie. Step 4: Scoop out the firm portion of canned coconut, which will sit on top after a few hours in the fridge. Whip coconut cream with vanilla and store in the fridge until ready to serve your healthy pumpkin pie. Enjoy!

title: Warm Up With This Simple and Amazing Butternut Squash Soup
body:
Few foods represent autumn better than butternut squash. Roasted, this vegetable caramelizes into a buttery, decadent treat. We've taken the roasting process one step further to create this simple yet incredibly flavorful butternut squash soup that will wow anyone. Fall is peak season for butternut squash, so the flavor will be at its best. In addition to serving as an ideal base for a blended soup, butternut squash has a number of health benefits. It's full of dietary fiber, which improves digestion and lowers the risk for heart disease. It's also rich in B6, which helps elevate your moods, improves brain function, and facilitates healthy blood pressure levels. The rich, orange hue of butternut squash can be credited to nutrients known as carotenoids. Carotenoids are a type of antioxidant commonly found in yellow, orange, and red produce. They protect eye health, prevent cardiovascular disease, help skin health, and even improve male fertility. Eating carotenoid-rich foods with fat helps improve its bioavailability to the body, so drizzling a little olive oil on top of the squash is a great idea for both flavor and health. Beyond adding even more taste to the butternut squash soup, sage has long been used for its medicinal purposes. The oils found in sage are both antiseptic and antibacterial, making it the perfect herb to choose as cold and flu season kicks into high gear. Sage is also rich in vitamin K, which helps activate proteins produced by the liver, ensuring proper blood clotting. Bone metabolism (which allows us to replace old bone cells with healthy ones) and the regulation of calcium in the blood are two other important tasks in which vitamin K plays a role. Choosing high quality, organic vegetable broth makes this butternut squash soup vegan and yields even more health benefits. The broth helps hydrate the body, which improves digestion, regulates body temperature, increases circulation and energy, and prevents muscle cramps. Additionally, the broth retains many of the antioxidants and minerals found in the vegetables and herbs used to make it. Saving produce scraps you'd otherwise toss and storing them in the freezer is a great way to utilize food waste and produce a homemade vegetable broth. Ingredients
  • 1 large butternut squash
  • 1/2 small onion
  • 1 small shallot
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • 3-4 cloves garlic
  • 1 small sweet potato
  • 4 cups vegetable or chicken broth
  • 3-4 thyme sprigs
  • 1-2 sage bunches
  • salt
  • pepper
Step 1: Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Cut butternut squash in half, scoop out seeds, and place on a baking sheet flesh side up. Coat in olive oil, salt, and pepper. Roast for 45-60 minutes, until flesh is golden brown and easily pierced with a fork. Step 2: While squash roasts, prepare vegetables. Peel and chop onion, shallot, and garlic. Pick off 5-6 sage leaves, and leave 1-2 sage sprigs whole (leaves attached to stem). Peel sweet potato. Step 3: Steam sweet potato until easily pierced with a fork. While sweet potato steams, add olive oil and onions to a saute pan over medium heat. Saute onions for 4-5 minutes, then add shallots and garlic, and saute for 2 additional minutes. Step 4: Pour broth over onions. Add thyme and sage leaves (the ones attached to the stem), and set the individual sage leaves aside for use later. Simmer for 10 minutes, then remove from heat. Remove sage and thyme and discard.   Step 5: Place sweet potato and squash flesh (scoop from skin) into blender. Pour over broth and blend on high. Step 6: Optionally, fry sage leaves in olive oil for 60-90 seconds until crispy and lightly browned. Top your butternut squash soup with sage and serve!

title: How to Make Healthy Homemade Granola Bars
body: Homemade granola bars can be a great healthy addition to packed lunches and after school snacks now that fall is in full swing. While pre-packaged foods are certainly convenient, we can't always guarantee they contain the most wholesome ingredients for our families. We've created these no-bake chocolate-cherry homemade granola bars filled will fiber, healthy fats, and flavors that kids and adults alike will love. Oatmeal for Heart Health The soluble fiber found in oatmeal has been linked to lowering bad cholesterol (LDL), which decreases the risk for heart disease. It also helps keep you satiated longer, improves digestion, and assists in the maintenance of lower body weight. Meanwhile, the antioxidant content in oats fights inflammation throughout the body, which is great for heart function and warding off diseases like cancer. Cherries for Restful Sleep We love the tart flavor of cherries to balance the sweet cacao in this recipe. Plus, they pack an even bigger antioxidant punch than oatmeal. The type of antioxidants found in cherries blocks inflammatory enzymes, promoting health and decreasing muscular and joint pain. Cherries are rich in many micronutrients, but specifically in melatonin and tryptophan, a calming combination that facilitates restful sleep. In one study, participants were given unsweetened cherry juice for two weeks, and on average slept soundly for 90 minutes longer than the control group. For these homemade granola bars, choose an unsweetened variety, as processed sugar is linked to breakouts, inflammation, and obesity. Cacao for Staying Calm Our homemade granola bars recipe uses cacao, which has more nutrients than processed cocoa powder, but the same great chocolate flavor. Cacao has a higher calcium content than cow's milk and is among the most reliable plant sources of iron. It's also known for magnesium, a mineral that is crucial for combating stress and staying calm. Magnesium has been shown to improve ADHD symptoms in children and reduce insomnia. If you choose chocolate chips over cacao, be sure to pick a darker variety with less added sugar. Almond Butter for Blood Sugar Regulation We've chosen wholesome carbohydrate sources for our homemade granola bars, but it's still important to pair them with healthy fats and protein to ensure sugars enter the bloodstream more slowly (the fiber content also helps with this). It's crucial to get a steady flow of energy from our snacks and meals, rather than a sharp increase that leads to a post-spike crash. Blood sugar stabilization helps with mood, appetite control, and sound sleep. Choosing raw nut butter keeps the micronutrient content higher. Almond butter provides a solid dose of monounsaturated fats (which are anti-inflammatory) and Vitamin E, which helps lower bad cholesterol levels. Ingredients: 2-3 cups rolled oats 1 cup cacao nibs, dark chocolate chips, or carob chips 1 cup almond butter 3/4 cup dried cherries 2/3 cup maple syrup or honey 1/4 cacao powder 1 tablespoon coconut oil 2 teaspoons vanilla 1/2 teaspoon salt Step 1: Add almond butter, maple syrup, coconut oil, and salt to a microwave-safe bowl. Heat in 15-second increments until warm enough to mix thoroughly. Step 2: Add cacao and vanilla to almond butter and mix thoroughly. Next add oats, chocolate chips, and cherries and fold in (optionally save some chocolate chips for the top of granola bars). Add the first two cups of oats first, then slowly add the third (if you prefer a dryer bar, add more oats). Step 3: Line an 8x8 pan with parchment paper and coat thoroughly with non-stick cooking spray. Spread granola mixture, and press with hands or spatula until it's flat and even. Spread the remaining chocolate chips over mixture and press lightly so they stick. Step 4: Freeze for one hour, then immediately remove from freezer. Cut into 12 bars and store in an airtight container for up to two weeks. Alternatively, you can keep in the refrigerator for 2-3 hours before cutting. Enjoy!

title: These Healthy Blueberry Muffins Make Mornings Wonderful
body: You've likely heard that breakfast is the most important meal of the day. There are countless benefits to eating a nutritious breakfast — including a higher metabolism, weight loss, normalized blood sugar, and a better mood. Unfortunately, mornings can also be hectic, so adding a healthy but delicious breakfast to your routine may feel impossible. Grab-and-go breakfasts make sense when you’re pressed for time, but too often people reach for sugar-filled pastries or other easy but unhealthy options. We have a solution. Try these healthy blueberry muffins, which are gluten free, loaded with antioxidants, and contain no processed sugar! Healthy Blueberry Muffins Deliver Antioxidants Healthy blueberry muffins take advantage of one of nature's most nutritionally beneficial fruits. Blueberries are high in antioxidants. What does that mean? Many stressors, ranging from smoking to exercising, can lead to the formation of free radicals in our bodies. This creates a risk for excessive inflammation, damage to our DNA, and chronic issues like cancer and heart disease. Some free radical formation is normal, which is why the body produces antioxidants on its own. However, this function decreases as we age, and it simply isn't sufficient to deal with the level of toxins we are exposed to through modern pollution, stress and diet. As a result, it is crucial to consume antioxidants through our diet. Many organic vegetables and fruits are rich in antioxidants. Blueberries are believed to have the highest concentration among common fruits and vegetables. They are particularly high in flavonoids, a type of antioxidant that gives blueberries their rich color, and are also helpful in detoxifying our system. Choose Whole Flours and Sugars We've chosen oatmeal rather than processed white flour for this healthy blueberry muffins recipe. Oatmeal is denser in fiber, which facilitates digestion. It also helps lower cholesterol and slows the rate at which sugars enter the blood stream. Coconut palm sugar is also known for having a milder impact on blood sugar levels. It is important to choose foods that don't cause spikes in our blood sugar in order to create more stable hunger levels, mood, and a healthier weight. When we regularly eat foods that cause jumps in blood sugar — like white bread, pasta, and sugary desserts — we also risk insulin resistance and eventually Type 2 diabetes. Ingredients for Healthy Blueberry Muffins: 6-12 ounces blueberries (depending on your preference) 2 cups oats, made into flour (see directions below) 2 large eggs, lightly beaten 2 tablespoons coconut oil 1 banana 1/4 cup almond butter 1.5 teaspoons baking powder 1/2 teaspoon baking soda 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1/3 cup coconut palm sugar or maple syrup 1 tablespoon flax seeds 1/2 cup almond milk 1/2 teaspoon vanilla 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4-1/2 cup oats for topping muffins (optional) Step 1: Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Place oats in a high-speed blender or food processor. Blend until a flour consistency is achieved. Next, add all ingredients except blueberries to the blender. Blend until a smooth batter is achieved. Step 2: Wash blueberries and toss with the batter.   Step 3: Line muffin tins with baking cups and lightly coat with non-stick spray. Equally, distribute batter into 12 muffin tins. Step 4: Bake for 20 minutes, or until an inserted toothpick comes out clean. Let cool, then enjoy these healthy blueberry muffins!

title: EHE Guidelines for Good Health After Hurricane Harvey
body:
Tropical Storm Harvey continues to devastate the Gulf Coast, with record rainfall still pounding the region. Millions of Americans in Houston and countless small towns across Texas and Louisiana are now facing destructive, deadly flooding. EHE's thoughts are with everyone affected by the storm and its aftermath. We have a clinic and affiliated physicians in Houston, as well as family, friends, colleagues, and clients throughout the area. While a catastrophe like Harvey creates emergencies that make personal care incredibly difficult, it's never more important than during a disaster to follow basic medical protocols to ensure your safety. Please read the following EHE recommendations for staying healthy in the wake of the storm. Hygiene and Drinking Water While basic hygiene is always important, it's especially vital during floods when floodwaters can carry sewage, pesticides, and other highly dangerous substances. Be sure to wash your hands and face with water that's been boiled or disinfected to reduce your exposure to germs. Similarly, if your community's tap water has been contaminated or compromised, only use properly cleaned water to drink, prepare food, or brush your teeth. See the Centers for Disease Control's (CDC) recommendations for making water safe in an emergency. Infectious Disease While new outbreaks of diseases not common in the United States (such as cholera or typhoid) will not occur after Harvey or similar storms, other communicable illnesses like diarrhea and respiratory illnesses may spread due to compromised public sanitation, crowding in shelters, and other factors. Pay attention to specific alerts from local and state health departments. Most importantly, do everything possible to maintain personal hygiene and the integrity of your food and water. The CDC also advises people in post-hurricane flood zones to be careful to protect against mosquitoes since the insects can carry a number of diseases and thrive in standing water. Here is additional information on specific infectious diseases associated with natural disasters. Tetanus Floodwaters can contain debris that may cause cuts or puncture wounds and those same waters could be contaminated with bacteria which is why there is a heightened media focus on the risk of contracting tetanus however, infectious disease experts caution against public panic regarding tetanus. While tetanus infection is serious, mere exposure to floodwaters is NOT in and of itself a reason to get an immediate tetanus booster shot, despite certain reports. If you sustain a wound during a flood, it should be evaluated for possible tetanus treatment no differently than it would be in a non-disaster situation. If you've already been vaccinated on the CDC-recommended schedule (a booster shot every 10 years for adults), no additional vaccination is necessary. In most cases, properly treating wounds and consulting with a doctor if you are not sure of your tetanus vaccination history should be the guiding protocol. Safety When Reentering Your House If your home is flooded, it is imperative to take extreme caution when you return. All utilities — electricity, natural gas, propane, etc. — must be shut off to avoid potential electrocution or explosion. Depending on the extent of the flooding, dangerous downed power lines may be obscured, sewage or metal debris could be in the water, ventilation of carbon monoxide could be blocked, and other hazards could be present. Always consult with the police and fire departments, as well as local utility providers, to determine whether it's safe to enter the house. For more information, see CDC guidelines on reentering flooded homes and additional cleanup recommendations. Mold A major health risk in the coming weeks and months will be the mold in buildings hit by rain and flooding. Experts say that any structure flooded during an event on this scale should be presumed to contain mold if not thoroughly dried within 48 hours. Given the prolonged nature of this storm, the mold issue could be particularly widespread. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has recommendations for residential flood cleanup, and the CDC has a checklist of the first and most important steps to take to combat flood-related mold. A comprehensive and more detailed guide to mold from both agencies can be seen here. Mental Health Natural disasters trigger spikes in stress and anxiety, can worsen existing mental health problems, and often impede standard mental health care delivery. If you are experiencing emotional distress due to the storm and need help, contact the National Disaster Distress Helpline. It is multilingual, critical crisis support, available toll-free and 24 hours a day via phone (1-800-985-5990) and SMS (text ‘TalkWithUs’ to 66746). For more help in coping with the trauma caused by emergencies like Harvey, see these mental health resources at the Department of Health and Human Services. Animals With floodwaters disrupting the environment and displacing species of every kind, there are widespread reports (and social media documentation) of fire ants, snakes, alligators surfacing in areas in and around Houston where they’re usually not spotted. Wildlife experts advise people to exercise the same common sense they would in normal circumstances: Stay clear, even if the animals don’t seem dangerous. Be especially vigilant, given how floodwaters can keep animals hidden until they’re very close. And, when reentering your home after it’s safe, be sure to check for any animals that may have taken up residence amid the storm.
For anyone hoping to assist those in the disaster zone, here are some ways to help: The American Red Cross is accepting donations online (click here) and via text (you can give $10 by texting HARVEY to 90999). Local organizations like the South Texas Blood & Tissue Center are facing desperate blood shortages. Donors nationwide can help — visit America's Blood Centers or the American Red Cross or the Armed Services Blood Program to find a donation site close to you. Americares is facilitating the delivery of emergency medicine, water, and supplies to those affected by Harvey; visit the site to donate. You can also donate to local groups, including:
  • Hurricane Harvey Relief Fund, established by the Greater Houston Community Foundation.
  • Houston Food Bank
  • United Way of Greater Houston

title: This Terrific Mediterranean Quinoa Salad Is Great for Your Heart
body:
A Mediterranean diet wards off disease, promotes wellness, and keeps weight healthy and stable. But what characterizes this approach to nutrition? Well, you'll find people in the Mediterranean region eating lots of fresh vegetables and fruits, unprocessed grains, seafood, high-protein (and high-quality) dairy, raw nuts, and, of course, olive oil. If you're looking to eat this way, most of your grocery shopping can be done around the perimeter of the store (think proteins and tons of produce), with limited trips to center aisles for certain grains, nuts, and legumes. While you may not be changing your whole diet just yet, we encourage you to try this flavorful Mediterranean quinoa salad as a delicious gateway to Mediterranean cuisine. Mediterranean Quinoa Salad: An Excellent Source of Protein Quinoa is one of the only plant protein sources that is a "complete" protein. The body produces many amino acids on its own, but there are nine amino acids we must consume in food, and they are crucial for survival. These are called essential amino acids, and quinoa contains all nine of them. Just one cup of this heart-healthy grain has eight grams of protein, meaning regularly including it in your diet can shave off the number of animal products you need as protein sources. Lowering your overall consumption of animal products is great for the environment and lowers your risk of diseases like cancer and heart disease. This Mediterranean quinoa salad is the perfect way to get protein. Olive Oil Promotes Heart Health Olive oil is rich in monounsaturated fats, which are often missing in the modern American diet. The fatty acids in olive oil are called oleic acid. Oleic acid has been shown to reduce inflammation throughout the body, which promotes health and helps to prevent a slew of diseases. In addition to the health benefits of its type of fat, olive oil also contains a concentration of antioxidants shown to fight free radicals, improve skin health, and prevent cancer. The antioxidants can be damaged by exposure to light and heat, so always store olive oil in a dark and cool spot. It's All About the Herbs  Every ingredient in this Mediterranean quinoa salad was chosen to promote health. Each vegetable is rich in antioxidants, which are important for counteracting the damaging pollutants, poor food choices, and stress we face each day. But it's not just the veggies that improve our wellness - both garlic and parsley come with their own benefits, too. Garlic in its raw form will not only add bite to the dish, but also stimulate the immune system and help fight off illness. Parsley is an herb you'll find in many Mediterranean dishes. It has long been used in the region to help diabetic patients, as parsley has been shown to keep blood sugar levels stable. Adding it to your dishes can help prevent insulin resistance, maintain energy levels, and even fight irritability. It's a great way to top this Mediterranean quinoa salad. Ingredients:
  • 2 cups quinoa, uncooked
  • 1 cup cucumber
  • 1 cup cherry tomatoes
  • 1 lemon
  • 1/2 small red onion
  • 1/3 cup olives
  • 1/4 cup parsley
  • 1/4 cup olive oil
  • 1-2 cloves garlic
  • 1/2 cup feta cheese (optional)
Step 1: Cook quinoa according to packaging. Once it's cooked, let cool to room temperature. Step 2: Prepare vegetables. Cut cucumber in half length-wise, then into slices. Slice tomatoes in half. Slice lemon in half. Cut red onion into thin slices. Cut olives in half. Remove stems and mince parsley. Mince garlic. Step 3: Add all vegetables and herbs (reserving 1/4 of parsley) to quinoa. Pour over olive oil and squeeze the juice of the entire lemon onto the salad. Add feta cheese if using. Toss to combine, then top with remaining parsley. This recipe can be served immediately or stored in the refrigerator for a week. Enjoy!

title: This Is the Best Grilled Shrimp Skewers Recipe
body:
Summer is barbecue season, but that doesn’t mean you have to stick to steaks and hot dogs. We love seafood as an alternative, and shrimp has many healthy advantages. This recipe for grilled shrimp skewers adds a nutritious, delicious option to your menu. It’s easy to cook, and the flavorful sauce can be stored in the fridge for a week, making it simple to prepare in advance. See how to make these incredible grilled shrimp skewers with pesto sauce below! Behold the Nutritional Power of Shrimp Shrimp is an excellent low-calorie source of protein. A dozen shrimp can total just 85-100 calories while packing 15 grams of protein! Protein is a crucial macronutrient to include at every meal. Aiming for at least 15-20 grams per meal is a good general goal in order to increase satiety, keep you full longer, and maintain muscle mass. Muscle burns more calories than other forms of tissue, so maintaining muscle is a great way to improve metabolic function, boost energy, and strengthen overall health. A useful guideline is that each meal should keep you full for 4-6 hours, which helps to prevent mindless snacking or impulsive food choices. If you're hungry much sooner than 4 hours after a meal, it may mean you ate too little, had simple carbohydrates which caused a blood sugar spike and quick drop, or didn't include enough protein. Besides keeping you full, protein slows the rate at which food is digested and absorbed. This helps to steady blood sugar levels, thereby stabilizing mood and energy, as well as preventing diabetes. Shrimp is also rich in selenium, a mineral that helps to counter free radicals and oxidation throughout the body. It's also been shown to prevent certain types of cancers. Selenium's anti-inflammation and -oxidation properties also decrease the risk of heart disease. Additionally, good thyroid health necessitates adequate selenium since it's required for the production of thyroid hormone. The thyroid regulates metabolism, which affects weight and energy levels. Selenium also boosts immunity, helping ward off common colds and the flu. Pesto Sauce Boosts Flavor and Health The pesto sauce in this recipe comes with many of its own health benefits. Mint is incredible for digestion, helping to fight inflammation in the gut and keeping things moving smoothly. Spinach is high in fiber, meaning it's also good for digestion, and because it's served raw it retains full micronutrient advantages. Garlic is incredible for immunity; it's antibacterial and antiviral, helping to ward off bad bacteria in the digestive tract. It also contains allicin, which stimulates immunity cells and keeps your immune system at peak performance. Overall, these grilled shrimp skewers offer a lot in the way of both nutrition and taste. Ingredients: Shrimp:
  • 1 lb large, raw, peeled shrimp
  • 1 lemon
  • olive oil
  • salt and pepper
Sauce:
  • 1/3 cup pine nuts
  • 1/2 cup mint
  • 1 1/2 cup spinach
  • 2-3 cloves garlic
  • 1/2 cup olive oil
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • 1 tablespoon parmesan or pecorino cheese (optional)
Equipment:
  • barbecue grill
  • skewers
Step 1: Rinse, peel, and dry shrimp. Thread shrimp onto 4-5 skewers. Brush with olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Set aside. Step 2: Make sauce. Add all sauce ingredients except olive oil to food processor. Pulse until roughly chopped, then continue to pulse as you slowly add olive oil, until desired texture is reached. If using cheese, fold in finely grates cheese once done processing. Step 3: Heat BBQ to medium high. Once hot, place skewers on BBQ, and cook for 2-4 minutes per side. Step 4: Squeeze lemon over shrimp and toss with pesto. Serve the grilled shrimp skewers immediately!

title: How to Save Sun Damaged Skin
body:
Sun damaged skin becomes more of a problem as we age. Excessive exposure to the sun’s ultraviolet (UV) rays can cause changes to the skin collectively known as photoaging. The dermatological development is characterized by a coarse and dry skin appearance; other features include freckling, discoloration, a leathery look, and deep wrinkles. Sun damaged skin can happen to anyone, not just those who go tanning regularly or work outdoors. The right course of action for managing the effects of photoaging depends on its severity, as well as factors such as your age and overall health, the specific type of damage sustained, and how well you tolerate certain therapies and treatments. You may also have an inclination toward the general type of treatment, whether you prefer natural options or a more standard medical approach. Of course, aging cannot be avoided entirely. But good skin care, combined with a healthy diet and lifestyle, will slow some of its physical impact and soften the effects of time and sun exposure. If you have sun damaged skin due to photoaging, you can improve its appearance and avoid further harm. Here are some options to prevent and reverse the effects of too much sun on your skin. Natural Treatments for Sun Damaged Skin
  • Aloe Vera - Aloe vera is one of the most effective natural remedies for sun damaged skin. It contains 150 trace elements and minerals such as calcium, magnesium, sodium, copper, zinc, selenium, potassium, iron, and amino acids. For best results, go directly to the source and cut open an aloe vera leaf, extracting the gel. Apply the gel directly to your skin, let it dry, and then rinse with cool water. Reapply several times per day to heal and soothe your skin.
  • Honey - Honey is a natural antibiotic and helps trap moisture to the skin. It also contains natural antioxidants, which are found in particularly high amounts in the darker varieties of honey. These antioxidants help to heal and neutralize free-radical damage to the skin from the sun, pollution, and stress. At-home skin treatments made with raw, dark honey will help to improve the tone, texture, and moisture content of your skin.
  • Lemon Juice - Lemon juice contains natural alpha hydroxy and glycolic acids that gently exfoliate the skin to improve texture and uneven skin tone caused by sun damage. You can make a homemade toner by mixing one tablespoon of fresh lemon juice with a half cup of pure water. Apply to the skin with a cotton ball or pad, and let it dry for 30 to 60 minutes. You can then leave the preparation on your skin or rinse with cool water.
  • Vitamin A - Eat foods rich in vitamin A, such as eggs, fish, and brightly colored vegetables, as part of a healthy overall diet featuring fresh, natural foods. Vitamin A is a natural antioxidant that promotes the healing and regeneration of sun damaged skin.
Medical Treatments for Sun Damaged Skin
  • Prescription Retinoids - Retinoids help even skin tone, and increase the amount of collagen in your skin, facilitating a more youthful appearance. A doctor can prescribe a retinoid cream or serum, like Retin A, for a full-strength effect. You can also opt for the less potent, over-the-counter form of retinol.
  • Microdermabrasion - Microdermabrasion gently sands and exfoliates the skin with small crystals, grains, or diamond tips. The process removes the outermost layer of skin, promotes the growth of collagen, and improves hyperpigmentation due to sun damage.
  • Laser Therapy - Short pulses of intense, concentrated light remove targeted layers or areas of the skin’s surface, reducing facial wrinkles, scarring, blemishes and uneven skin tone.
  • Chemical Peels - Chemical peels remove sun damaged skin from the upper layers. You can apply some peels, such as alpha-hydroxy or salicylic acid creams, yourself. A deeper peel is performed by a dermatologist.
While some of the effects of photoaging can be reversed and significantly improved, prevention is your best bet. Wear a broad spectrum (containing UVA and UVB protection) sunscreen with SPF 15 or higher, every day, regardless of your skin color or tone, and whether it’s sunny or cloudy outside. Regularly wearing protection from the sun’s rays will, over time, help reduce the appearance of previous damage while also decreasing your chances of developing skin cancer and further problems.

title: How Workplace Stress Hurts the Bottom Line
body:
Workplace stress is a huge problem for employees and companies alike. According to researchers, it costs U.S. businesses as much as $407 billion per year, and is a major contributor to cardiovascular disease. This is a staggering health and financial crisis. At least half of all workers are believed to suffer from stress and tension, and 66 percent of all employees report that their work performance suffers as a result. Poorly managed stress is the main cause of long-term employee absenteeism, and medical experts say that unmanaged stress is the primary cause of illnesses representing up to 70 percent of visits to primary care physicians. Research shows that chronic stress harms cognitive function and creativity, problem solving skills, decision making, motivation, planning, the ability to effectively strategize, morale, retention, and revenue. Chronic stress undermines employee wellbeing on multiple levels, as well as any company goal that depends on a healthy workforce. Clearly, stress management should be an essential component to any company’s employee health care program. The long-term costs in terms of medical bills, interpersonal conflict, errors, and absenteeism are far more financially draining to businesses than the cost of good stress management and preventative health care programs. Workplace Stress is Contagious Humans are intrinsically social, and we mirror one another’s moods and emotions. Therefore, stress symptoms spread among people who work closely together. Employees are also impacted by the stress levels of disgruntled supervisors, management personnel, and their organizing teams. The dynamics of employees’ various office interactions and interpersonal relationships all have a direct bearing on their stress levels. Employee Wellbeing Means More Than Physical Health Maintaining good health requires attention to nutrition and exercise, of course, but physical care alone is insufficient in ensuring overall wellbeing. The management of workplace stress is essential to preventing chronic illness. Ample research shows that when employees experience stress from work, financial, or family concerns, their health suffers and productivity declines. What is the Cost of Workplace Stress? Health management company StayWell evaluated the costs of stress, comparing them to those associated with 10 other common health-risk factors. The analysis determined that while obesity, tobacco use, alcohol dependency, high cholesterol, and hypertension comprised 25 percent of companies’ overall healthcare expenditures, stress was the single most costly risk to both employees’ health and an employer’s bottom line. How and Why Does Workplace Stress Cause Illness? When the brain detects stress, its fight or flight response is activated. Heightened levels of stress hormones – cortisol and norepinephrine – are released into the bloodstream. Over time, if this response becomes chronic, the body will start responding with symptoms linked to a person’s particular physical vulnerabilities. Some individuals will have panic attacks; others may begin having migraines, cardiovascular issues, or problems regulating blood sugar. Stress reactions can also be behavioral: poor eating habits, reliance on tobacco, or alcohol dependency and drug abuse can be responses to chronic stress as well. Ideas and Solutions for Workplace Stress Management
  • Provide low cost yoga, tai chi, and/or gym memberships for employees
  • Allow employees the option of working from home one day per week
  • Offer meditation classes
  • Encourage a one hour lunch break taken away from the office, or at least a full half-hour break
  • Replace vending machine junk food with healthy snacks and pure water
  • Encourage breaks away from the desk - particularly when stress hits
  • Organize meetings outside when possible
  • Invest in stress management and preventative health care programs for employees
American work culture has become increasingly stressful in recent decades. Our healthcare system sometimes neglects the impact of psychological factors and how they influence our overall health. In order to prevent and manage chronic illnesses, thereby lowering healthcare costs, it is essential to create office environments that offer workplace stress relief and management to employees.

title: The Benefits of Meditation Are Amazing
body:
Science is proving what many have known for centuries: the benefits of meditation are exciting and profound. There are countless ways to meditate and innumerable advantages. Discover what works for you by exploring different approaches, and then be sure to invest the time in making it a routine part of your life. A regular meditation practice enhances creativity and productivity at work, and it improves long-term health outcomes in a variety of areas. As little as five minutes of meditation a day can quickly reduce stress and anxiety. But the benefits of meditation go beyond that. Spending 20 minutes to an hour each day meditating (even for just a few weeks) is scientifically demonstrated to:
  • Increase and enhance the body’s immune response.
Researchers from Harvard Medical School have shown that subjects who practice yoga and meditation have improved mitochondrial energy production and function, which results in increased immunity and resilience against stress.
  • Improve cognitive function and focus.
In a study conducted at the University of California, meditators showed a sharp increase in their ability to focus, particularly on boring or repetitive tasks. Subjects also improved their performance in tests of cognitive skill and information processing, and in some cases demonstrated ten times the ability of the non-meditating group. There is also evidence that regular meditators develop a thicker prefrontal cortex and right anterior insula, and that a consistent meditation practice can offset cognitive decline in old age.
  • Prevent and reduce addictive behaviors and emotional eating patterns.
Scientists have found that meditation reduces emotional eating, and increased mindfulness generally helps us avoid unhealthy indulgences. A healthy diet is a cornerstone of any good preventative health care plan, and the benefits of meditation include the facilitation of positive habits in this regard.
  • Decrease anxiety, mood disorders, and depression.
In a study conducted in Belgium with 400 students ranging from 13 to 20 years old, an in-school mindfulness meditation program decreased incidents of depression, stress, and anxiety. Students were also shown to be less vulnerable to pronounced and major symptoms of depression with regular meditation practice. Another study shows that mindfulness meditation practice helps those with a history of depression to decrease cognitive dysfunction, negative thinking patterns, and rumination.
  • Improve self-esteem.
A healthy sense of self-esteem helps us commit to self-care, and make positive choices for ourselves in order to improve our health and our lives: all key components to a sound preventative health care plan. Meditation helps us learn to observe and question our thoughts as they arise. Instead of being swept up in an internal mental narrative, particularly a negative or overly critical one, we learn to create space around our thoughts and emotions in order to examine them. We also learn to release thoughts which harm us or hinder our sense of intrinsic self-worth. Authentic self-esteem is supported by an understanding of our inherent value and worth, and this is a sense of self we don’t have to prove. Mindfulness meditation is a powerful way to improve self-esteem, and as a result we tend to make healthier and more compassionate choices for ourselves. Popular Meditation Styles 
  • Mindfulness Meditation – This technique aims to create a non-judgmental and relaxed ability to observe thoughts, sensations, and emotions as they arise on a moment by moment basis. The technique is as simple as setting aside time each day to sit, focus on deep belly breathing, and experience these internal events as they unfold. Mindfulness trains us to declutter the mind, and become more present and observant of the world around us. Instead of operating on auto-pilot, we learn to pay attention in each moment of our lives.
    • Apps for Mindfulness Meditation Training
      • Headspace - A great app for people learning meditation for the first time, Headspace offers 10 free beginner-focused, mindfulness meditation sessions of 10 minutes apiece. Once you have completed this “Take 10” set, the app unlocks additional meditation sessions for purchase as you progress.
      • Smiling Mind - This app offers meditation sessions for all age groups, from children to adults. Educators can also use Smiling Mind to create meditation time in the classroom.
      • Stop, Breathe & Think - Offering 55 guided mindfulness meditation sessions, as well as a mood tracker and customizable chimes, the Stop, Breathe & Think app has programs designed to assist with depression, sleep, anxiety, and cultivating greater compassion.
  • Transcendental Meditation – This technique is taught for a fee by a certified teacher. Transcendental Meditation is a silent mantra style of meditation which does not involve the self-monitoring of mindfulness techniques. TM is considered helpful as a way to increase relaxation, stress relief, and personal development.
  • Vipassana Meditation – This technique is one of the most ancient, and has been taught in India for more than 2500 years. Vipassana is taught free of charge by trained instructors, with donations requested as able, during 10-day training sessions around the world. This training involves mental focus on the breath while contemplating the nature of impermanence, or change, in order to generate greater peace and self-understanding.
Regardless of the meditation style you choose, consistency is key. In order to reap the myriad benefits of meditation, it is important to establish a regular practice. The more we meditate, the better we will feel. Meditation makes individuals happier, physically and mentally healthier, and better equipped to deal with stress. The benefits of meditation can no longer be ignored.

title: The Best Healthy Picnic Food to Make This Summer
body:
Summer is the perfect time to revel in gorgeous weather and enjoy as much time outdoors as possible. Picnics are one of the season’s greatest pleasures, whether you’re celebrating the Fourth of July or Labor Day, or just spending a long, sunny day at the beach. Healthy picnic food can be delicious, too. When planning what to pack for your next al fresco dining adventure, think about forgoing the typical fried chicken, potato chips, and hot dogs in favor of healthier, fresh, whole food options. Here are some ideas for healthy picnic food:
  • Garlic Rosemary White Bean Dip - This creamy dip is perfect for whole grain crackers, baguettes or sliced raw veggies, and is easy to prepare and transport. This is also a great spread for layering in a (whole grain) sandwich or wrap.
  • Fresh Fruit Kabobs - Fruit kabobs are a fun, beautiful and healthy treat. Grab some skewers and layer up however you’d like: try a combination of strawberry, grape, melon and pineapple, or make your own with your favorite fruits.
  • Mango Avocado Quinoa and Black Bean Salad - This salad is a gorgeous, protein-packed alternative to the heavy, mayonnaise-laden standbys, and is perfect as a side dish or a vegetarian main course.
  • Sriracha Rainbow Noodle Salad - Beautiful, colorful and delicious, this noodle salad is another amazing example of how to build a better, healthier picnic meal.
  • Garlic Herb Turkey Burgers - Made with organic turkey and fresh garlic and herbs, this burger is an excellent grilling option. Pair with lots of veggies and your favorite toppings, and wrap in a romaine leaf or on a whole grain bun.
  • Spicy Party Mix - This mix is a great, healthy alternative to prepackaged snacks and chips.
  • Gooey Sweet Potato Brownies - These brownies are a great example of how to make whole food substitutions for your favorite treats and get a delicious and indulgent result. Bonus: kids would never guess that these are packed with nutrient-rich sweet potatoes.
  • Better Beverages – You’ll definitely want to hydrate with a quality water bottle like the ones from Tervis, but what other drinks should you bring? Try to ditch the sodas (even diet versions); processed sugars and artificial sweeteners should be limited as much as possible. Instead, fill your cooler with pure filtered water, unsweetened ice tea, and lemonade sweetened with a little stevia or raw honey.
More Healthy Picnic Food Ideas Pack your picnic basket with fresh hummus and whole grain pita, a veggie tray with a healthy dip, fresh berries, nectarines, and watermelon. Chopped vegetable salads you prepare early (without the lettuces) will taste even better the following day and are perfect for picnics. Lightly marinated grilled vegetables are wonderful as a side dish. As you continue to explore healthier, more plant-focused options, try to find whole foods bloggers and experiment with their recipes. We all have emotional attachments to less-than-ideal meals and snacks, especially those we grew up with. The transition to healthy eating can seem daunting at first. But whole, natural foods can be every bit as satisfying and flavorful, while providing incredible nutritional advantages compared to overly processed, industrially produced foods. As you learn how to make healthier substitutions for your old favorites, you will feel and look better. And there’s no better way to start than by packing healthy picnic food on a beautiful day.

title: This Recipe for Salmon Burgers Is Easy and Perfect
body:
Summertime usually means lots of barbecues - typically filled with hot dogs, greasy chips, and burgers doused in cheese and mayonnaise. We've created this salmon burgers recipe as the perfect alternative to the standard barbecue menu. The salmon is juicy, flavorful and accompanied by a garlicky, creamy sauce. You won't miss any of the classic treats once you try this salmon burgers recipe, a fun way to get some great nutrition. Eat Salmon Burgers for DHA and EHA Content We often hear that we should be eating more fish, but few of us actually get the 2-3 weekly servings recommended. We love these salmon burgers because you can easily freeze the patties and pop them into a pan for a quick dinner. Eating salmon adds a healthy dose of protein, which is the building block of our muscles and hormones. It also helps keep us satiated for longer. The fish is full of micronutrients like B vitamins and potassium. Most importantly, salmon is an excellent source of Omega-3s, which are typically under-consumed in the modern American diet. The Omega-3s found in salmon (and other oily fishes) are called eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). You've probably seen supplements with these two names advertised - and for good reason, as they contribute to many functions throughout our body.
