Cultures in which the cuisine features regular fish consumption tend to have significantly lower rates of heart disease and high blood pressure. EHA and DHA are also crucial for brain function - improving memory, preventing depression, and lowering the risk for Alzheimer's disease. Choose Healthier Bread Products Traditional wheat products like white flour and breadcrumbs can trigger weight gain, blood sugar issues and inflammation throughout the body. For this salmon burger recipe, we've replaced breadcrumbs with almond flour, which is made by grinding almonds into a powder. Almonds add heart-healthy fats and additional protein as well. We've also suggested choosing sprouted or gluten-free buns. Sprouted wheat is healthier than whole wheat because it is more digestible. All grains contain phytic acid, which protects the plant but also inhibits our ability to absorb the nutrients. Sprouted bread products are less processed, so they also retain more of their nutrients. If you want an even lighter option, these patties are just as delicious served in a lettuce wrap. Ingredients: Salmon burgers:
  • 1 lb fresh salmon
  • 1 egg
  • 1/4 cup almond flour
  • 1/2 small yellow onion
  • 1/2 jalapeño
  • 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder
  • 1/2 lemon
  • 1/2 teaspoon paprika
  • 1/4 teaspoon salt
Avocado sauce:
  • 5.3 ounces of Greek yogurt (a single serving cup)
  • 1 avocado
  • 1 lemon
  • 1-2 cloves garlic
  • 3-4 basil leaves
  • salt
For serving:
  • red onion
  • butter lettuce
  • sprouted or gluten free buns
Step 1: Make sauce. Remove stems from basil. Remove skin and pit from the avocado. Juice lemon. Add all ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth. If the sauce is too thick, you can add water slowly to thin it out. Set sauce aside. Step 2: Remove skin from the salmon and cut into smaller chunks. Peel the onion and cut in half, setting one half aside. Cut jalapeño in half lengthwise and remove seeds, setting one half aside. Add all burger ingredients to a food processor and pulse until fully minced and combined. Step 3: Divide salmon mixture into four equal portions. Mold each portion into a burger patty. Heat one tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat in a non-stick pan. Cook for 4-5 minutes on each side, or until golden brown and cooked through. Step 4: Serve salmon immediately with thick slices of red onion, your avocado sauce, and buns or butter lettuce to wrap.

title: The Work / Life Balance is a Skill You Need to Pursue
body:
Many people find the work-life balance challenging to navigate. In addition to heavy workloads we have families, friends, self-care, and personal interests to attend to, all of which are important to our overall happiness and well-being. Often, we are met with overwhelming demands in multiple areas of our lives, and it can be difficult to develop a strategy for balancing the various responsibilities we face. Once we are chronically overloaded our stress hormone levels spike, productivity and relationships suffer, and we become more vulnerable to lowered immunity and illness. With some structure and a bit of strategy, however, we can learn to manage stress, and achieve better balance and quality of life. Strategies for Work
  • Boundaries: If you are in the habit of taking on every responsibility and project that comes your way it might be time to learn the art of saying no. Be realistic about how much you can take on at a given time. Depending on your profession, you may have more or less control over your workload, but wherever you do have a say, you can learn to draw a line when you need to. Learn to say no.
  • Work from Home: Again, this is profession specific, but whenever possible ask for flexibility with your schedule. Even telecommuting one day a week from home can help alleviate stress. Many companies are becoming savvy to the importance of work / life balance, and are adopting policies to prevent workplace stress, so find out what your options are.
  • Take Breaks: Breaks are necessary throughout the day, and you are entitled to take a pause when needed. When you start to feel fatigued, frustrated, or overwhelmed, get up from your desk, take a walk, get some fresh air, and engage some deep breathing to reset. Apps like Accupedo can motivate you to track your daily activity and stay active.
  • Set Reasonable Expectations: Perfectionism in work and in life is linked to chronic stress and illness, so go a little easy on yourself. Bring your best to what you do, but understand that mistakes, or a less than perfect job performance at times, are normal. Remember that performance tends to suffer when we are pushed past capacity, so delegate where and when you can, and ask for help when you need it.
  • Draft a Daily To-Do List: Set manageable goals each day and keep track of them. By drawing up a daily list of priorities and tasks to achieve, and staying on top of them as you complete them one by one, you will feel a sense of mastery over your workload which reduces stress and the feeling of being overwhelmed.
Strategies for Home
  • Practice Self-Care: Identify what you need to feel your best, be healthy, and regulate when you are stressed and upset. Self-care is for you: the more you are able to reset your energy and cope with stressors, the more you have to give to your relationships and other areas of your life. Exercise, meditation, journaling, listening to music, time alone, walks in nature, avoiding upsetting media during certain times, pursuing hobbies or personal interests, are all examples of ways to practice self-care. Think about the things you enjoy that recharge and help you feel renewed and refreshed on an ongoing basis. Good self-care is something you can learn to weave throughout your daily and weekly schedule. Self-care also makes you more stress resilient overall.
  • Delegate: Take steps to ensure that responsibilities at home are fairly distributed among household members so that no one person is carrying the majority of the weight. Draw up chore charts and lists, or clearly discuss who will be responsible for what on a daily and / or weekly basis.
  • More Boundaries: Carve out distraction free time with loved ones. Maybe you decide that work brought home is only done in a designated area (like an office) at set times, but devices and work at the dinner table are off limits. Maybe you commit to dinner as a couple / family four nights a week while leaving the other three open for other work and social commitments. Decide what works for you based on the needs of your household.
  • Eat Well: Do your best to keep your diet based on whole, fresh, and natural foods, and take the time to eat in a mindful way. Prepare your own meals as much as possible, and avoid stressful conversation at meal times.
  • Cultivate Friendships: Social support is key to a good work / life balance. Supportive friendships reduce stress, isolation, and strengthen the immune system. Have at least one or two people you can trust and confide in; social support is good for your mental and emotional health, and makes you more stress resilient in all areas of your life.
Maybe you have a good balance in some areas of your life, but need to shore up others; perhaps you are starting from scratch. Begin from where you are and know that it is possible to improve no matter how daunting the process may seem. One powerful way to strengthen your work / life balance is to release time wasting activities and relationships. If someone or something is more of an energy and time drain than an asset, assess if you can afford the investment of your precious time. Figure out what your priorities are and make them your main focus.

title: Benefits of a Physical Examination as Preventative Health Care
body:
A physical examination is more than a check-up; it’s one of the best ways to boost longevity and health in the long term by committing to preventative care and medical screenings. Proactive measures help you and your doctor identify potential health risks, making it easier to avoid and interrupt chronic illness before it takes hold. This is why it is important to see your doctor for annual physical exams. We know that visiting the doctor is intimidating for many, and we encourage you to confront any fear you may be feeling and make the appointment. Your doctor is a partner in creating good long-term health outcomes, and the peace of mind which comes from taking positive action is worth the nerves and effort. While overcoming fear of doctor’s visits sounds great in theory, in practice it feels overwhelming for some at first. Anxiety about medical care is common, and can be difficult to manage at times. When calling to make your medical appointments, it is helpful to communicate your concerns to the individuals responsible for scheduling. Maybe you have a fear of needles, and you want to ensure you are seen by your doctor’s best and most sensitive phlebotomist. By communicating your needs to your care providers, you give them the opportunity to accommodate you and make your visit as comfortable as possible. Happy Side Effect of a Physical Examination It is important to remember that scheduling an annual physical examination is just one part of making the commitment to self-care and better health choices. Lifestyle habits such as exercise, proper sleep habits / hygiene, nutrition, stress management, and medical care are all key to supporting your health over time. As you learn to find ways to commit to lasting change, you can be sure that your efforts will pay off. Benefits such as better sleep, healthier body weight, increased energy, and better mental clarity result from taking charge of your health and well-being. Some Things to Consider Before Your Physical Examination
  • Preventative care will help decrease and ease anxiety over time by protecting your health in the long term.
  • A proactive approach to health care includes developing healthier lifestyle habits such as exercise, sleep hygiene, and stress management which contribute to the prevention of many chronic and degenerative diseases.
  • Preventative medical screenings help protect your financial future. Illness is far less expensive to prevent than it is to treat.
  • Annual medical screenings actually reduce your time spent in the doctor’s office by decreasing the likelihood of more complex illnesses developing over time.
 Action Steps:
  • Choose a type of exercise you enjoy, and commit to it at least three times per week.
  • See your doctor regularly for physical exams.
  • Eat a nourishing and balanced diet based in whole, natural, and minimally processed foods.
  • Do not smoke. If you do smoke, talk with your doctor about the right smoking cessation program for you.
  • Drink alcohol in moderation or not at all.
  • Get at least seven to eight hours of sleep each night. Turn off your phone and electronic devices at least one hour before bed, and sleep in a well darkened room.
Remember that your health and peace of mind are worth the effort it takes to protect them, so we encourage a proactive approach. Know that any anxiety you may feel about seeing your doctor is understandable, however, over time, a preventative health care approach will decrease health related anxieties, protect your financial future, and increase your wellness and longevity for years to come.

title: Top 10 Signs You Might Have Seasonal Allergies (and How to Deal with Them)
body:
Seasonal allergies touch the lives of most of us at some point. According to the CDC, 20 million adults in the US have been diagnosed with hay fever in the past 12 months. Spring seasonal allergies can start as early as February and can last well into the summer. Trees that produce large amounts of pollen are one of the main triggers. A particularly rainy spring or mild winter can cause trees and plants to grow more rapidly, producing larger amounts of pollen and leading to a more severe allergy season. This can also cause an increase in the growth of mold spores which are another major allergen. 10 Major Symptoms of Seasonal Allergies:
  • Coughing
  • Sneezing
  • Nasal congestion or runny nose
  • Postnasal drip
  • Fatigue or low energy
  • Itchy, red or swollen eyes
  • Watery eyes
  • Allergic Shiners (dark circles under the eyes as a result of congestion)
  • Itchy throat or roof of the mouth
  • Rash or itchy skin

Who is Susceptible to Seasonal Allergies?

Anyone can develop seasonal allergies during various stages of life. A child may grow out of their allergies by adulthood. Allergens triggering major reactions may diminish or increase from season to season. And moving from one climate to another could cause you to develop allergies that perhaps you were never aware of. How to Prepare for Seasonal Allergies One of the best ways to ease the affect of your seasonal allergies is to keep an eye on the pollen and mold spore counts which are normally announced in newspapers or news broadcasts during the allergy season. Keep your windows closed during the season and run the air-conditioner during days with particularly high pollen counts. You may also consider a home air filter or air purifier. Prevention of Seasonal Allergies Allergies are not preventable, but your allergic reactions can be minimized. The best form of prevention is understanding what triggers or causes your allergies. Visiting an allergist can help you determine your triggers and prescribe treatment. An allergist may prescribe medications or help you with advice on avoiding allergens such as remaining in an air-conditioned area during days with particularly high pollen counts. Seasonal allergies may be something you have to live with over the course of your life, but you don’t have to suffer. By preparing for the season, understanding your triggers, and through the use of medications or avoidance, you can make your seasonal allergies much more bearable.

title: Should You Join an Adult Recreational Sports Team?
body: Are you bored with your exercise routine? Tired of staring at the TV while on the elliptical or treadmill? Did you play sports your whole life until the reality of adulthood and a 9 to 5 job brought playing to a grinding halt? If any of these scenarios sound familiar to you, it might be time to shake up your routine and join an adult sports team! Even if you’ve never set foot on a court, field or diamond, if there’s a sport you’ve always wanted to play but never learned, joining an adult sport league can be a great way to learn a new skill, exercise and have fun! If this sounds like something you’d like to try, you most likely have a lot of questions. What sport should you play? Where are you going to find a team? What if you’ve never played before? Read on for some tips on what you could play, where to look and what to expect. The good news is that depending on where you live and work, there are often quite a few sports and activities to choose from--volleyball, softball, basketball, soccer and even kickball, dodgeball and ultimate frisbee! Start by checking with your local YMCA or your city’s parks and recreation department—they often have leagues already set up. There’s usually a fee to play but it is relatively inexpensive. Another possibility is to ask if your job has any workplace sponsored teams you could join. And if those don’t yield results, do an internet search for phrases like “adult basketball league in (your city)” or “coed softball league in (your city)” as these will often produce good results. If you’re just a beginner and worried about not being good enough for a team, don’t let that stop you! Some leagues have different levels of play available from beginner to more advanced. My city for example, has beginner, intermediate and advanced divisions in its volleyball league.  Start out in the beginner league and as you improve you can move on to the next level of play. Or start with something that doesn’t require a lot of athletic prowess, like kickball! You can go to WAKA and put in your zip code to see if there are any leagues near you! (I just did it and found 1 locally and 2 others within an hour of my house!) Although joining a team may sound appealing, you may be wondering if it is really practical. Between work and family obligations who has the time for this? But remember that everyone else is dealing with time constraints too, so you can probably find something that will work with your schedule. If you’re still not convinced to give it a try, consider these benefits of joining an adult sports league that you may not have considered. You can: Meet new people and expand your social circle: Joining a team is a great way to meet people and make new friends. You already know you share at least one interest with the other members of your team, so it’s a good way to break the ice and get to know your teammates even better. There’s nothing quite like the camaraderie you build through teamwork on the playing field. Relieve stress: Playing in a basketball game or a beach volleyball game (or whatever your sport of choice is!) can be a great way to de-stress and blow off steam after a long day at work. It gives you the opportunity to get away from it all and escape from the routine of the workweek and the worries of daily life. I think we could all use a healthy escape like this from time to time! Have fun!: The importance of play doesn’t end with childhood. Sometimes we forget this as we grow older. Play bring joy and who doesn’t want more joy in their life? When you’re having fun playing a team sport you are engaged and connected and these feelings can be a tremendous boost to your mental health. Variety: Going to the gym every day or for a jog is certainly admirable and great for your health, but it’s also good to mix things up once in a while. When you play a team sport you’ll add variety to your workouts, you’ll get a change of scenery and you may have so much fun that you forget you’re exercising! Of course, you can’t overlook the very important fact that when you are physically active you are healthier. And we are all more likely to be physically active and stay physically active when we enjoy what we are doing! That’s why joining a sports league may be just the thing--not only will you get moving and reap the physical benefits of exercise, you’ll have fun doing it!

title: Creating A Box Garden
body:
The first time I tried a box garden, I wasn't sure what to plant. I decided to go to my local farmers market and told them what my family enjoys eating and asked if any of those vegetables grow well in our area. I was in luck because lettuce, carrots, peppers, radishes, and tomatoes were on the list, and my family loves salad. And bonus, this mix of vegetables plants happens to be easy to care for!  We decided to start with a small box garden to give it a trial run the first year we did it. From my experience as a beginner box gardener, here are a few tips to get started.
  • Box garden, well, in a box! If you don’t want to invest too much time, you can purchase a kit that comes complete with pre-measured and cut lumber and hardware-how handy! Avoid building a boxed garden on a wooden deck as the weight might be too much for the deck to bear. If you build directly on a concrete patio be sure to raise the box garden so there is proper drainage.
  • By design box gardens need little space. Make sure the location you choose will get an appropriate amount of sunlight and is close to a water source. Fill the box garden up to about three inches from the top with a good-quality mix of nutrient-rich soil and compost that is best suited for the plants you want to grow. Make sure it is level and smooth once filled. Keep the soil moist, but be careful not to over-water your garden.
  • Spacing of plants can be closer than a normal garden but don’t overdo it on the seeds. Standard seed packets will have way more than you need as I found out when I used a whole packet of carrot seeds and grew these teeny tiny carrots the size of my pinky. Your first season may be an experiment.
  • Family project. My kids loved running to the garden to snip the lettuce and pull the radishes for the ultimate fresh salad. We were even inspired to make our own fresh dressing (recipe below). Take turns with watering, weeding and harvesting. The pride of gardening is contagious and so is the love of salads. We are eating more salad than ever—even froze some tomatoes for the winter months.
Now, to keep the squirrels away! Have you tried a box garden? What has worked for you, and what hasn't? BASIC VINAIGRETTE SALAD DRESSING                Ingredients (4 servings) 1/4 cup red wine vinegar, 2 tablespoons dijon mustard, 1 tablespoon minced shallot 1/4 teaspoon salt, 2/3 cup EVOO, Salt and pepper                               Preparation In a bowl, whisk together all ingredients except EVOO. Slowly drizzle in EVOO, whisking constantly; season with salt and pepper.

title: New Parents And Sleep
body:
It’s 3 a.m. and your baby is crying again. Does her diaper need changing? Is he hungry? Does she need to be changed and fed? Unfortunately, interrupted sleep is a fact of life for parents of a newborn which makes those first few months of parenthood utterly and completely exhausting.  It is not at all unusual for new parents to feel sleep deprived and wonder if they will ever get a good night’s sleep again. While a night of uninterrupted sleep is unlikely those first few months, there are strategies you can use to maximize the amount of rest you do get. Incorporating those strategies can help to alleviate some of the negative health consequences that can occur due to disrupted sleep. Effects of Disrupted Sleep This probably comes as no surprise, especially if you are currently in the midst of caring for a newborn…but adequate sleep is a vital component of your health and well–being, and when you don’t sleep well, many important aspects of your life can suffer including your mood, cognitive ability, attention span and energy level. Numerous studies support this conclusion including a study published in the November 2015 journal Sleep that examined the effects of three different sleep conditions—three consecutive nights of either forced awakenings, delayed bedtimes or uninterrupted sleep--on 62 healthy men and women. Results confirmed the negative consequences interrupted sleep has on your energy level and mood. The study found that after the first night the participants who were subjected to eight forced awakenings and those with delayed bedtimes showed similar low positive mood and high negative mood. After two nights however, the group with forced awakenings had a 31 percent reduction in their positive mood and the group with a delayed bedtime had only a 12 percent reduction in positive mood compared to the first day. Both groups had similar negative moods on all three days. The researchers discovered that the forced awakening group had shorter periods of deep, slow-wave restorative sleep than the group with the delayed bedtime, and the lack of this type of sleep had a statistically significant association with the participant’s reduction in positive mood. They also found that interrupted sleep not only reduced participant’s energy levels, but also reduced their feelings of sympathy and friendliness. Another study conducted on students and published in the July 2014 issue of Sleep Medicine, found a causal link between interrupted sleep patterns and reduced cognitive abilities, shortened attention spans, and negative moods. What Can You Do? Of course, the joys of new parenthood can go a long way towards making up for the sleep deprivation you feel, but you can also employ some strategies to help mitigate the effects of interrupted sleep. Most parenting experts suggest trying the following:
  • Sleep when your baby sleeps. This can’t be emphasized enough! When your baby naps, you nap. When your baby goes to bed at night, it’s time for you to go to bed too. Turn off your phone, computer, and tablet. Leave the dishes in the sink, the laundry in the hamper and any other household chores that aren’t finished for another time. Your sleep is much more important.
  • Split nighttime duties with your partner. This can be done in several different ways depending on your specific situation. If your baby is bottle fed, divide the night into four hour shifts, so each of you can get four hours of uninterrupted sleep, or alternate entire nights so each of you get a full night of uninterrupted sleep every other night. Another option is simply alternating who feeds and changes the baby each time the baby awakens. (You can even sleep in separate rooms during this time so the parent that is “off-duty” can get undisturbed sleep.) If the baby is breast fed, nursing mothers could pump a bottle of breast milk in advance so her partner can take a turn feeding the baby at night. If pumping breast milk is not an option, the partner can bring the baby to the breastfeeding mom and handle nighttime diaper changes.
  • Keep your room quiet, dark, and unstimulating. For overnight feedings and diaper changes, keep lighting as low as possible using a night light with low illumination, and keep distractions to a minimum.
  • Ask for and accept help: If any trust worthy adult in your life asks if you need any help, say yes! Have them spend time with the baby while you take a nap. Or, if your family members or friends want to visit say yes and ask them to let you take a nap to recharge.
  • Remember there is a light at the end of the tunnel: Although you may feel like you’ll never get a good night’s sleep again, remember that this too shall pass. Babies generally start sleeping for longer, more humane stretches of time by 3 to 6 months of age.
Being a new parent has many highs and lows—it is a joyful time and an exhausting time as well. While sleep deprivation is almost guaranteed in the first few months of your baby’s life, it is also possible to get some relief. Try some--or better yet all--of the strategies above to maximize the amount of rest you do get. Remember that a fundamental aspect of being a good parent is taking good care of yourself so you can take good care of your family!

title: Accepting the Challenge with Wearables
body:
Wearable technology (or “wearables”) have exploded onto the scene and have become the must have item for the holidays. Whether you’re rocking a Fitbit wristband or an Apple Watch, wearables have become a symbol of cool. But when used properly they can also symbolize good health. The selling point for wearables is in the trackers, or put another way in gathering data on particular health metrics. These devices are commonly used to track things such as steps, calories burned, heart rate, and even sleep hours. And when users log-in to their wearables’ website they can view this data on their dashboard. It’s almost like opening up the menu in a video game and viewing your character’s stats, but instead of leveling up in the virtual world you do so in the real one. Pretty cool! However, getting these stats don’t come cheap as this technology is essentially asking people to do what research has been telling them to do for years, which is to eat right and exercise. With that said, wearables have changed the conversation from a lecture to more of a challenge. Wellness programs within organizations have been getting a big push in the last decade as “lifestyle diseases” have become an overwhelming burden being responsible for 7 out of every 10 deaths annually and accounting for 86 percent of healthcare costs, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. And since incentives seem to be the way to go for organizations to promote wellness, tracking health metrics through a popular gizmo is just the medium to achieve this goal. But employees win out too as health challenges issued by the organization (e.g., to reach 10,000 daily for a month) allows employees to get creative to meet these goals and gives them the impetus to create their own challenges. Now when individuals go to work and see their co-workers rocking wearables a bond is formed as the shared experience of working towards a health goal creates a sense of unity and belonging. Wearables then become a source of pride, but only as far as the motivation to meet health goals is present.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

Wearables are uniquely placed in an area where health promotion is needed in an accessible format. However, novelty is short-lived where lasting change isn’t. In order for individuals and organizations to get the most out of wearables both must rise to the challenge of leveling up their health.

title: What is Dietary Fat?
body:
According to the Institute of Medicine’s (IOMs) Dietary Reference Intakes for Energy, Carbohydrate, Fiber, Fat, Fatty Acids, Cholesterol, Protein, and Amino Acids, dietary fat is a macronutrient that provides a major source of energy for the body--approximately 9 units of energy (or calories) per gram. While there are three main types of fats--saturated fats, unsaturated fats, and trans fats--according to Harvard Medical School all fats have a similar chemical structure. Fats are comprised of “a chain of carbon atoms bonded by hydrogen atoms.” What differentiates one type of fat from another is “the length and shape of the carbon chain and the number of hydrogen atoms connected to the carbon atoms. Seemingly slight differences in structure translate into crucial differences in form and function.”

Types of Dietary Fat

There are three main types of dietary fat: unsaturated, saturated, and trans. Unsaturated Fats: Often referred to as the “good” fats, unsaturated fats are either monounsaturated or polyunsaturated. According to the Harvard Medical School, unsaturated fats are usually liquid at room temperature and are found mainly in plant–based sources. Polyunsaturated fats are referred to as essential fats because the body requires them for good health but cannot synthesize them on its own, so they must be obtained from food. Unsaturated fats can be found in olive, peanut, sunflower, corn, soybean, and flaxseed oils; avocados; nuts; seeds; and fish. Unsaturated fats are considered to be beneficial because they may help improve and maintain blood cholesterol levels, reduce blood pressure, ease inflammation, and stabilize heart rhythms. Saturated Fats: According to the American Heart Association (AHA), “From a chemical standpoint, saturated fats are simply fat molecules that have no double bonds between carbon molecules because they are saturated with hydrogen molecules.” These fats can be found in red meat, butter, whole milk, dairy products made with whole or 2 percent milk, cheeses, palm and coconut oils, and many commercially prepared baked goods and fried foods. Interestingly, recent research has called the association between saturated fats and cardiovascular disease into question. A systematic review and meta-analysis examining the association between dietary fatty acids and coronary heart disease (CHD) published in the March 18, 2014 Annals of Internal Medicine, concluded that, “Current evidence does not clearly support cardiovascular guidelines that encourage high consumption of polyunsaturated fatty acids and low consumption of total saturated fats.” A meta-analysis of 21 studies that appeared in the March 2010 issue of The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition found that there was not enough evidence to conclude that saturated fat increases the risk of CHD or cardiovascular disease (CVD). Despite this conflicting evidence, the AHA recommends limiting saturated fats to less than 7 percent of one’s total daily calories because “Decades of sound science has proven it can raise your “bad” cholesterol and put you at higher risk for heart disease.” Trans Fats: There are two types of trans fats in the diet: those formed naturally and those created during food processing. Those formed naturally are produced in the gut of some grazing animals. According to the AHA, trans fats that are created during processing (also called “partially hydrogenated oils”) “are created in an industrial process that adds hydrogen to liquid vegetable oils to make them more solid.” The primary source of trans fats in the American diet are foods containing industrially–modified and partially–hydrogenated vegetable oils such as fried foods, pizza dough, pie crust, margarine, chips, and commercially baked goods such as pastries, cookies, doughnuts, and crackers. Artificial trans fats are harmful because they raise bad (LDL) cholesterol levels and lower good (HDL) cholesterol levels, which are risk factors for heart disease. The AHA recommends limiting artificial trans fats to less than one percent of total daily calories.

Benefits of Fats

Although the excessive consumption of some fats can cause serious health issues, individuals should not cut out fats altogether because fats are essential to health. In addition to providing the body with energy, fats serve many other important functions; according to Harvard Medical School, fats aid in:
  • The absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E and K as well as carotenoids
  • Blood clotting
  • Muscle movement
  • Inflammation
  • Building cell membranes
  • Building the sheaths that surround nerves
It is important to keep in mind that all fats are very high in calories and therefore must be eaten in moderation as part of an overall well–balanced diet. Unfortunately, according to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, 2015, the diets of most Americans contain far more fat than the body needs. The consistent consumption of excessive fat, particularly excessive amounts of the wrong types of fat, can lead to serious health complications. It is important for you to be aware of the fat content of the foods you consume and try to replace most saturated and trans fats with healthier unsaturated fats because these types of fats will help promote your health and well-being.

title: Digestive Health
body:
In the “Maintaining Health” series it was established that what you put inside your body determines, more than any other component, the trajectory of your health. This series, titled “Digestive Health,” will help you discover how food and drink is broken down; why the kinds of food that you ingest affect your digestion and consequently your health; and what you can do to keep your digestive system in optimal working condition.

Digestive Health: An Introduction to Digestion

Digestion is like breathing: it’s an important, automatic bodily process that isn’t given a second thought unless something goes wrong; but unlike breathing, digestion is complex and requires consistent maintenance. This article will inform readers what the digestive system is and how it works so they can begin to have a deeper understanding of its significance.

What is the Digestive System?

According to the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDKD), “The digestive system is made up of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract—also called the digestive tract—and the liver, pancreas, and gallbladder.” It is made up of hollow organs and solid organs. The hollow organs are the mouth, esophagus, stomach, and the small and large intestines. The solid organs include the liver, pancreas, and gallbladder. Together the components of the digestive system utilize muscle movements, digestive juices, enzymes, and bacteria to break down, extract, and distribute the nutrition present in foods and drink.

Digestion in Action

Digestion first begins in the mouth, a hollow organ that leads to the esophagus. The mouth uses mastication (chewing) in order to break down foods into smaller bits. While chewing is taking place, saliva is secreted by the salivary glands in the mouth to break down complex carbohydrates as well as to moisten the food bits so that they may be swallowed. Swallowing is performed by the esophagus, a hollow organ which leads to the stomach. Food that is swallowed is involuntarily pushed by the muscles in the esophagus towards the lower esophageal sphincter (the muscle that controls what goes into the stomach) in a process called esophageal peristalsis. Food passes through the esophageal sphincter and enters the stomach, a hollow organ that leads to the duodenum of the small intestine. Here, food is mixed with hydrochloric acid (to further break down food bits) and proteases (an enzyme secreted by the pancreas that turns proteins into amino acids). The stomach is lined with muscles that churn this mixture (via peristalsis) into chime--a mass of partly digested food. Chyme enters the duodenum of the small intestine to be further broken down. Digestive juices from the small intestine and pancreas combined with bile from the liver allow the food to be absorbed into the blood where it can be distributed throughout the body. Chyme that wasn’t fully digested for whatever reason is sent to the large intestine. The large intestine receives waste products and anything else that wasn’t fully digested in the small intestine. It absorbs any remaining water and nutrients before turning the waste into stool, where it is stored in the rectum (as part of the large intestine) to be discharged via defecation.

The Bottom Line

The digestive process utilizes many components of the body in order to turn food and drink into nourishment. Though as with any process with moving parts, it is subject to malfunction if routine maintenance isn’t upheld. In the next entry in the “Digestive Health” series, we will take a closer look at the components of digestion in order to keep your digestive system running at peak performance.

title: Attacking Anxiety with Action and Awareness
body:
The causes of anxiety disorders are not fully known, however, scientists believe that they are most likely the result of a combination of factors including changes in the brain, environmental stress, genetics, and psychological and developmental factors. Anxiety can also manifest due to medical conditions such as hyperthyroidism, heart failure or COPD, and the use of certain medications or drugs such as corticosteroids, cocaine, amphetamines, and excessive amounts of caffeine. Since the causes are varied in nature, but the end result (that of anxiousness) is still the same, the only way to treat anxiety disorders—without medication—appears to be to discover a pattern for symptoms and to try and then isolate triggers. This allows an individual to at the very least avoid a possible anxious situation. But avoidance is only half of the answer. While an anxiety disorder may not have a cure to the extent that the person afflicted will never have to go through extreme anxiety, it doesn’t mean that there isn’t a way to satisfactorily overcome the disorder. Once an individual knows what causes the anxiety to flare up they can preempt the negative experience by modifying their attitude and behavior going in to the situation as opposed to just reacting to it. For example, if a cramped space like a subway car or an elevator causes you anxiety, embrace the time spent in this triggering space by normalizing the area. This can be achieved by being mindful of your breathing, speaking to a stranger with a prepared, friendly greeting, or opening up your posture and putting a smile on your face to invite positivity. In the end mindfulness is key to overcoming social anxiety.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

Social anxiety in an age of virtual worlds, ever distancing relationships, and instant gratification is becoming a big problem. Because anxiety disorders cause extreme discomfort in the individual, escapism is one of the easiest solutions to employ—particularly because one can escape by simply taking out their phone. But the only way to overcome anxiety is to face it with the knowledge of one’s self. The mind is malleable and, if you suffer from an anxiety disorder, this fact along with the idea that the avoidance of anxiety inducing situations can only take you so far should help motivate you to kick anxiety to the curb.

title: Is Fitness Simply Based on Genetics?
body:
While the path to physical fitness is straightforward (i.e., dieting and exercise), this path starts to meander wildly when people attempt to actually follow it--lengthening the time it takes to reach the finish line, if ever. The question, of course, becomes "why?" Why are people hard-pressed to achieve fitness when every voice out there is saying that it's good? Not only that, but it is equally ubiquitous to hear that not being fit is bad. So why? An article in the NY Times poses an interesting answer: perhaps unfit people are simply not programmed to be fit. Citing a study published in the Journal of Physiology, the article summarizes the study by describing the findings. Essentially, rats that like to run on a wheel were bred with other rats that like to run on a wheel and they in turn produced rats that also like to run on a wheel. The opposite was true for rats that were not so inclined to run. This difference in the rats is attributed to genes encouraging certain neurons in the brains of running rats to mature and develop the drive to run. The rats that weren't inclined to run showed considerably less mature neurons in their brains. But before we put down the dumbbell in nihilistic fashion, the study also showed that even some non-running rats ran reluctantly. The professor that oversaw this study cautions that these findings shouldn't be attributed to people as the brains of rats and humans are different, and that "people can decide to exercise".

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

My personal opinion of this article and its cited source is that while genetics dictate whether you'll be an Olympic-class athlete, it doesn't dictate whether you lead a healthy life. Thoughts?

title: Knowing Your Healthy Self in 2016
body:
Living a healthy life is big on everyone’s radar from getting more sleep, to eating a nutritious diet, and doing enough exercise. But the New Year’s resolution trial period always seems to end at around two weeks. So this post will offer some tips on how to stay in the game for all four quarters and reap the rewards of finishing off a year in the ascension.

Planning to Suceed

One of the first things that individuals should do for a healthy life is plan for it. And while making a to-do list is nice and all, it doesn’t always get it done when it’s time. No, a real plan involves knowing what is holding you back from your health goals at the start and having things in place that keep you going when times get rough. An easy and common obstacle that many people fail to overcome is holiday get-togethers. While Thanksgiving and Christmas are far off, they will inevitably come around meaning that the reverie that prevails with being around family, friends, and food will block out a lot of the discipline that it takes to remain focused on health. Massive amounts of sodium, calories, alcohol, and other things will be consumed by many who feel entitled to being unhealthy, but that shouldn’t be you…and it won’t if you plan.

Don't Undervalue the Short Game

Looking ahead is a way for adults to put themselves in a favorable position. In fact, those who fail or simply don’t bother to look ahead are generally criticized as needing to mature. But to get to tomorrow you must live today. Any change takes time to make into a habit, and with health it takes even longer to see positive outcomes. Instead of giving up or tapering off after an unknown time, individuals should focus their New Year’s health-related resolutions on the day-to-day. If you’ve made a plan to get healthy and know what it takes then completing those objectives everyday will ensure that you get to the end of the year with progress made.

Mindset Determines Trajectory

The biggest pitfall for New Year’s health-related resolutions is the reward aspect. Many people feel like they should reward themselves for doing good. This is an extremely slippery slope as once unhealthy habits—habits that have been formed for years—start gaining acceptance, whether it’s once a year, once a month, or once a day then the doors are open for it to become part of one’s lifestyle. The sacrifice of going without and knowing that the change has lasted one more day should be the reward, and while it is excruciating at first, the longer an individual delays gratification the more likely that delay becomes the reward in and of itself.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

As the song in the musical goes, “Change never comes easy.” New Year’s resolutions have been broken by so many people so many times that it has become a farce. This is unacceptable as a resolution requires resolve. If your resolution this year is to live a healthy lifestyle then you must plan ahead, live day-to-day, and let the work you put towards your goals be its own reward.

title: Food Substitution: One Thing Leads to Another
body:
Back in June of this year, the Journal of the American Medical Association released some interesting news: The 2015 Dietary Guidelines would lift the ban on dietary fat—previously the recommendation was to have no more than 35 percent of calories in one’s diet coming from fat. This change comes partially from the behavior of substitution and how simplifying problems typically lead to more problems with greater complexity. According to the article, since “fat contains about twice the calories per gram as carbohydrate or protein, it was also reasoned that low-fat diets would help prevent obesity, a growing public health concern.” So to challenge obesity, low-fat and low-calorie products became the norm; however, these products substituted dietary fat for refined calories and added sugar. Substituted things are typically not of the same quality as the thing they are substituting, and such is the case with products that tried to substitute fat. Rather than lowering obesity and the risk for cardiovascular disease, low-fat products ironically increased these numbers because everything boiled down to getting total fat to zero on the nutrition label. Obesity is a complex problem that has numerous causes working with each other to create the epidemic that still continues to this day. Even if an individual were to eat what is considered a healthy diet, this by itself won’t change everything. Indeed, those who go from one unhealthy practice to a healthy one might substitute another unhealthy practice for the one that they gave up, yet the substituted practice is actually worse than the one before it. For example, a person decides to substitute cakes and other desserts with fruit in an effort to curb added sugars and fat. But because there is a void in this person’s sweet tooth rather than eat sugar he/she will drink them instead as his/her consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages rise. This makes the problem worse because now the individual is actually consuming more added sugar than before, but considers it to be ok because he/she has stopped eating desserts.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

When it comes to your health there is no substitution. Processed and refined foods will always take a back seat to those that are unprocessed and unrefined, such as whole fruits, vegetables, and grains.

title: The Prescribed Painkiller Problem in the U.S.
body:
People suffer from many issues, from psychological, to emotional, and of course physical, but dealing with these issues sometimes compound the problem rather than alleviating it; for instance, painkillers are commonly prescribed for those who are in pain, however, many prescribed painkillers (such as Oxycontin, Vicodin, Percocet, and their generic incarnations/derivatives) contain the inherent risk of dependence, whether it stems from a psychological dependence from being prescribed this medicine for a particular issue, an emotional dependence from the thought of having to deal with life without the effects of the drug, or a physical dependence from the drug’s active ingredient. A person’s pain threshold varies, not to mention it is impossible to measure pain outside of an individual asking the person suffering of the intensity of the sensation on a scale of 1 to 10—so prescribing pain medicine is a tricky situation. Nevertheless, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) states that: “The United States is in the midst of a prescription painkiller overdose epidemic.” And while the amount of prescribed painkillers has quadrupled since 1999, there “has not been an overall change in the amount of pain that Americans report.”

The Physicians are Prescribing, which means…?

According to a recent MedlinePlus article, primary care doctors are the leading prescribers of narcotic painkillers with 28.1 million prescriptions being issued in 2013, data which was gathered by looking at “Medicare Part D prescription drug coverage claims.” Additionally, nurse practitioners and physician assistants issued 7.2 million prescriptions in their own right. With these figures in mind, it comes as no surprise that the CDC reports that: “Every day, 44 people in the U.S. die from overdose of prescription painkillers, and many more become addicted.” So what is being done? What can be done? The article concludes by saying education in better prescription practices, increased oversight on healthcare providers, greater community awareness, and a willingness from both sides to curb habit-forming treatment as being the keys to success in the endeavor to reduce the painkiller epidemic. Another key component in reducing the amount of lives affected by prescription painkillers is to focus on preventive healthcare. While accidents happen and pain from different sources can be inevitable, treating the problem shouldn’t make it more severe. Preventive healthcare, which conditions patients to keep an eye on their health, while also giving them the support they need in order to accomplish their health goals will enable them to manage their situation better than just relying on prescribed medicine to magically fix the situation.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

Being prescribed painkillers doesn’t mitigate the risk inherent in these drugs. It simply allows individuals the ability to consume them in a (hopefully) controlled environment. But the fact of the matter is that people are overdosing or becoming addicted to these drugs at an increased rate that coincides with the amount of prescriptions being issues, all without reducing pain. So what does that mean? It means that magic beans can grow into a giant beanstalk leading to a golden solution to pain, but you must first evade the giant looking to keep you trapped in his castle.

title: Putting on Modified Genes
body:
An individual’s genetic makeup has a lot to do with how they live their life: It determines if they will be predisposed to certain behaviors and diseases, and if they will inherit certain traits. Genes are so influential to animals, plants, and microorganisms (which all pass along their genes to their offspring) that the manipulation of them has become an area of great study, and great concern because the consequences of passing on engineered genes have unknown consequences so far.

Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs)

According to the Non-GMO Project, GMOs “are living organisms whose genetic material has been artificially manipulated in a laboratory through genetic engineering, or GE.” And while this source is admittedly biased, there is basis for concern as they go on to state in their FAQ that: “Most developed nations do not consider GMOs to be safe. In more than 60 countries around the world, including Australia, Japan, and all of the countries in the European Union, there are significant restrictions or outright bans on the production and sale of GMOs. In the U.S., the government has approved GMOs based on studies conducted by the same corporations that created them and profit from their sale. Increasingly, Americans are taking matters into their own hands and choosing to opt out of the GMO experiment.” So why do GMOs persist if they are considered unsafe by many? The answer is that being able to create organisms that have desired traits, such as crops that resist herbicides and animals that grow larger and faster, is profitable, practical, and can lead to scientific breakthroughs, such as cures for presently incurable diseases. But these benefits come into conflict by purported issues that arise from genetic engineering, such as more pesticides used on crops and leading to people being more prone to allergies and cancer. However, there are no conclusive studies that correlate GMOs to these negative claims.

Human Genetic Modification

While GMOs are the beginning, the natural end result of being able to manipulate the genes of organisms is to be able to do it with people. With that said, there has been a notable rejection of this potential use of genetic engineering from the Center for Genetics and Society (CGS). With an upcoming International Summit on Human Gene Editing, the CGS released an open letter detailing why they have chosen to take this stance. Of particular note are the themes of inequality and the lack of control that will pervade such a scenario once people have control of what genes get passed on.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

According to Healthline, “GMO seeds are used to plant 90 percent of corn, soybeans, and cotton grown in the U.S.” This means that Americans are almost guaranteed to have consumed and will continue to consume GMO products. There are proponents on both sides of the GMO debate, and while there are no conclusive studies connecting GMOs to many of the negative claims that come from those that oppose them, the fact remains that many prominent countries have made it clear that they want nothing to do with GMOs. On top of that, when it comes to genetic modification in humans, even scientists are extremely hazardous of the consequences, both known and unknown.

title: Working Memory in the Information Age
body:
The information age can broadly be defined by the famous Steve Jobs quote about “…standing at the intersection of computers and humanism.” This is to say that the prevalence of data processing machines in a society that bonds through the passing of information is where we are now, and will be for the foreseeable future. While the ability to communicate and collaborate instantly across vast distances has been a boon, the access this has granted us to each other and to large data stores has allowed for a certain issue to arise: How do people with limited working memory behave when their lives have been integrated with machines which have unlimited recall?

What is Working Memory?

Working memory is the mechanism that allows individuals to recall and organize critical pieces of information, usually simultaneously, so that said information can be applied to a certain task. A common example used to illustrate working memory is mental arithmetic where a person hears two numbers and must add, subtract, multiply, or divide these numbers in their head and produce an answer. As the numbers grow larger, the ability for the individual to process this data and generate an accurate solution diminishes. This example can be contrasted with a computer which can take exponentially large numbers and perform calculations on them instantly. In the APA’s “A workout for working memory,” two different theories regarding the limits of working memory were presented. On the one hand you had the theory of working memory being limited to seven different pieces of information at one time (such as recalling up to seven digits in a sequence), with anything greater having to be chunked (e.g., dividing a 10-digit number into chunks of five) for recall. This theory was contrasted with the idea that individuals can only retain one item in working memory, and the “n-back” test was employed to prove this. The n-back test, by the way, is when: “The participants [in the task] read a series of numbers, presented one at a time on a computer screen. In the easiest version of the task, the computer presents a new digit, and then prompts participants to recall what number immediately preceded the current one. More difficult versions might ask participants to recall what number appeared two, three or four digits ago.” As you can imagine, the recall times varied when recalling the previous digit in a sequence and recalling the digit that was presented four sequences ago. In the end, however, the article revealed that a study was able to improve recall times after participants practiced the n-back test for 10 hours in a five day span, meaning that working memory can be improved. But is there a cost?  

Working Memory Overload and Cognitive Performance

In a study found on the National Institute for Biotechnology Information, researchers utilized the stress placed on individuals during the n-back test and monitored subsequent cognitive performance. The results were interesting. As you can imagine, the recall times among the individuals increased as they were tasked with recalling numbers further back in sequence; however, what happened when individuals had to recall numbers four sequences back and then were asked to recall a number only two sequences back? The study finds that: “Overloading the working memory system with a high-load 4-back task induced a significant decline in subsequent working memory function and robust decreases in brain activity in various regions including relatively large areas of the pre-frontal cortex.”  

The Bottom Line – For Your Health!

With so much information being consumed by individuals at one time (count how many tabs you have open in your internet browser), it can be argued that many people place high-loads on their working memory at a pretty consistent rate. On top of that, information consumption and processing doesn’t only happen at work. As these high-loads of information recall have been shown to have a negative effect on cognitive performance, individuals should try doing one thing at a time.

title: The Secret to Good Health, Now With Even More Evidence!
body:
The NY Times recently posted an article with the headline “Cutting Sugar Improves Children’s Health in Just 10 Days,” where they cite a study where foods with added sugar (as distinct from naturally-occurring sugar found in fruits) were removed from children’s diets and replaced with carbohydrates to keep overall calorie intake the same. This is significant because added sugar is typically refined sugar and is therefore stripped of all nutrients, essentially making them empty calories. But we’ll get back to that. After the 10 day period, the results were considerable: While weight was unaffected during this time, their metabolic health changed significantly. If you were wondering, metabolic health is how well you break down and utilize the nutrients and minerals found in foods and beverages. “Good” foods such as fruits and vegetables are easier to break down and provide numerous macro and micronutrients—in other words they offer more bang for your buck and help maintain your metabolism. “Bad” foods, typically those that are highly processed and refined, do the opposite. But this is somewhat common knowledge. The truly shocking facet of this study is how quickly metabolic health was affected once added sugar was removed. From the article: “On average, the subjects’ LDL cholesterol, the kind implicated in heart disease, fell by 10 points. Their diastolic blood pressure fell five points. Their triglycerides, a type of fat that travels in the blood and contributes to heart disease, dropped 33 points. And their fasting blood sugar and insulin levels – indicators of their diabetes risk – likewise markedly improved.” To further the point about how significant this is, the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention remark that as of 2012, “about half of all adults—117 million people—had one or more chronic health conditions.” These conditions, also known as lifestyle diseases (think about that), include “heart disease, stroke, cancer, diabetes, obesity, and arthritis—are among the most common, costly, and preventable of all health problems.” So by know I think you know where I’m going with this: This study showed how quickly added sugar destroys the body and begins to set the foundation for chronic disease later on in life. Unhealthy individuals don’t just become unhealthy; they always were, since childhood.

The Bottom Line – For Your Health

Refined sugars are stripped of all macro and micronutrients making them “empty calories.” But the misconception is that “empty calories” simply cause weight gain, when in realty they cause weight gain through the deterioration of one’s metabolism—which of course leads to other problems besides having a gut. And on the topic of guts, alcohol (such as the seemingly innocuous beer) contains refined sugars, refined carbohydrates, and an addictive agent as a nice cherry on top. So what did we learn? The mountain of evidence tells us to cut out added sugars (and on a related note alcohol) from our diet. But the marketing for these products will encourage consumption. As always the choice will be yours…

title: Healthy Concerns for Women
body:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, according to the World Cancer Research Fund; additionally, breast cancer is 100 times more likely to develop in women than in men, which means that simply being a woman is a huge risk factor for the disease. This brings up a very interesting issue: how does being a woman affect one’s health? The answer, according to MedlinePlus, is quite significantly. With October designated as “Breast Cancer Awareness Month,” the parade of pink ribbons should serve as a reminder that women must take their overall health seriously. Medline Plus states that, “Women have unique health issues. And some of the health issues that affect both men and women can affect women differently.” These unique health issues involve being pregnant, going through menopause, and being at greater risk for certain conditions—namely breast cancer and osteoporosis. In addition to unique health problems for women, MedlinePlus states that:
  • "Women are more likely to die following a heart attack than men
  • Women are more likely to show signs of depression and anxiety than men
  • The effects of sexually transmitted diseases can be more serious in women
  • Osteoarthritis affects more women than men
  • Women are more likely to have urinary tract problems”
A woman’s body goes through many changes over the course of her life, and these changing conditions create a greater chance for complications. As this is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, getting a mammography screen—particularly in middle aged women—is important; but more important is for all women to take a step back and evaluate their overall health. Ask yourself: Am I getting enough vitamins and nutrients in my diet? Do I exercise regularly? Have I had a pap test done? Am I heart healthy? Am I considering getting pregnant? Am I already pregnant, and if so have I visited a midwife or obstetrician? Am I approaching menopause?

The Bottom Line – For Your Health

While breast cancer may not seem like a pressing concern for some women, use the marketing that surrounds this month as a reminder to ensure your overall health.

title: Don’t Contract With Contacts
body:
Wearing contact lenses is typically a convenient and safe form of vision correction, but sometimes convenience breeds complacency. Keeping your contacts clean and maintained is of the utmost importance because these medical devices are placed directly on the eye, and unhygienic use will eventually cause certain eye infections and vision problems. And while this may appear obvious, it isn’t unheard of for contact lens wearers to forget to wear, wash or store their lenses properly, or even discard them after prolonged use. Actually that last point—about it not being unheard of for contact lens wearers to exhibit unhygienic behavior—is an understatement. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention:  “An estimated one in six adults in the United States wears contact lenses, and one third of them report at least one health care visit for a red or painful eye while wearing lenses. Approximately 99% of contact lens wearers reported at least one risk behavior ever for eye infections or inflammation. Of particular concern, contact lens wearers of all types frequently reported exposure of their contact lenses to water, including storing or rinsing their lenses in tap water and showering or swimming while wearing lenses.” This is very revealing. It means that contact lens wearers are among the most at-risk for eye infections. And it's not only because they neglect to care for their contacts. A recent study by NYU Langone reports that the bacteria present in the eyes of contact wearers is different from that of non-wearers: “Specifically, the NYU Langone team found that the eye surface, or conjunctiva, has surprisingly higher bacterial diversity than the skin directly beneath the eye and three times the usual proportion of Methylobacterium, Lactobacillus, Acinetobacter, and Pseudomonas bacteria in the eyes of the study’s nine contact lens wearers than is typically found on the surface of the eyeballs of 11 other men and women in the study who did not wear contact lenses. When measured and plotted on a graph, statistical germ diversity scores showed that the eye microbiome of contact lens wearers had a composition more similar to that of the wearer’s skin than the eye microbiome of non-lens wearers.” 

The Bottom Line – For Your Health

It is almost ironic that the devices used to improve one’s vision so that he/she may have a greater quality of life may, in the end, cause that person to have diminished or lost vision. In the end, contact lens wearers should be more prudent with their vision.

title: Considering Men’s Health
body:
September is considered “National Prostate Cancer Awareness Month,” where numerous organizations and experts seek to raise awareness for prostate health, inform about the risk factors for prostate cancer, and encourage prostate screenings. This month is right before “National Breast Cancer Awareness Month” (October) where there is a similar push for awareness and prevention, but this time for the breasts. Both men and women can get both types of cancers, but prostate cancer is much more prevalent in men and breast cancer is much more prevalent in women, inevitably causing gendered associations. While October enjoys a flood of pink ribbons (the symbol used in support of breast cancer), you’d be hard-pressed to find a blue ribbon (the symbol used in support of prostate cancer) in September—which underpins a major issue: Men’s health, in general, needs a major push so that men of all ages can be made aware of their increased risk for disease and death.

A Proclivity for Lifestyle Diseases

According to Healthfinder.org, compared to women, men are more likely to:
  • “Smoke
  • Drink alcohol
  • Make unhealthy or risky choices
  • Put off regular checkups and medical care”
These behaviors are all common risk factors for lifestyle diseases—those that are associated and brought upon by how an individual lives. These diseases, according to Medicinenet.com, include “atherosclerosis, heart disease, and stroke; obesity and type 2 diabetes; and diseases associated with smoking and alcohol and drug abuse.” Additionally, lifestyle disease is becoming more of a problem in the U.S. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: “The five leading causes of death in the United States are heart disease, cancer, chronic lower respiratory diseases, stroke, and unintentional injuries. Together they accounted for 63 percent of all U.S. deaths in 2010, with rates for each cause varying greatly from state to state.”  Unsurprisingly, the Kaiser Family Foundation finds that life expectancy of a man is several years fewer than that of a woman, which speaks nothing of the quality of life that a man who smokes, drinks, and makes unhealthy choices leads.

The Bottom Line

From this we can gather that men are a prime audience for preventive healthcare and education. Unfortunately, the reason for this is because they are more susceptible to unhealthy behavior. As this month is Prostate Cancer Awareness Month—essentially a month designated for men’s health considering the gendered association—and seeing the extreme push that occurs for Breast Cancer Awareness (which is typically aimed at female health), now is the time for men to consider their current and future states of health.

title: The Moderation Conundrum
body:
You’ve probably heard or seen the phrase “Please drink responsibly” or have read the studies purporting the benefits of moderate alcohol consumption and thought to yourself, “I knew a couple of beers wasn’t that bad.” But to do something in moderation requires one to know what is considered extreme, and when it comes to alcohol consumption, considering recent trends, what may appear as moderate drinking could quietly be a binge drinking environment in reality.

Understanding Alcohol and the Standard Drink

Alcohol is also known as ethanol, and is a neurotoxic, psychedelic chemical compound that is formed by the fermentation of sugars and yeasts. It is absorbed in both the stomach and small intestine where it is metabolized by liver enzymes. When alcohol is broken down and absorbed by the body its properties produce an intoxicating effect on the individual with the effect becoming more pronounced the higher one’s blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level. The National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA) states that, “A standard drink is any drink that contains about 14 grams of pure alcohol (about 0.6 fluid ounces or 1.2 tablespoons).” This translates to 12 oz of a beverage containing 5 percent alcohol, 5 oz of a beverage containing 12 percent alcohol, and 1.5 oz  of a beverage containing 40 percent alcohol all constituting one “standard drink.” And according to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, moderate drinking is up to one standard drink per day for women and up to two standard drinks per day for men. While this may seem easy enough to abide by, the problem occurs when a standard drink serving (of 12 oz for example) doesn’t come with standard alcohol content for the serving size. The Health Services at Brown University state that: “Understanding the rate of metabolism is critical to understanding the effects of alcohol. In general, the liver can process one ounce of liquor (or one standard drink) in one hour. If you consume more than this, your system becomes saturated, and the additional alcohol will accumulate in the blood and body tissues until it can be metabolized.” And as CNBC remarks, craft beers “whose sales grew 22 percent to $19.6 billion in 2014 and continued a four-year streak of double digit growth, is driving a sea change in American palates with heavier doses of alcohol.” What this means is that Americans crave the type of beer that comes with higher alcohol content, yet the serving sizes of these craft beers are typically 12 oz. So if you drink a 12 oz beer with an alcohol by volume (ABV) of 10 percent, then you’ve just had two standard drinks in one sitting and there is roughly 14 grams of pure alcohol floating in your system waiting to be metabolized.

Drinking Levels Revisited

The NIAAA states that, “binge drinking as a pattern of drinking that brings blood alcohol concentration (BAC) levels to 0.08 g/dL. This typically occurs after 4 drinks for women and 5 drinks for men—in about two hours.” And that heavy drinking is, “drinking 5 or more drinks on the same occasion on each of 5 or more days in the past 30 days.” As you may have noticed these higher levels of drinking are defined by BAC and not how many beer bottles you’ve accumulated. For example, if you had two bottles of a 12 oz craft beer with a 10 percent ABV you might consider your drinking habits to be in moderation, but with the higher alcohol content, these two beers would cause your BAC to go up to 0.055g/dL as opposed to 0.027g/dL as it would with two “standard” drinks. The increased demand for craft beers with high ABVs, the drinking culture established in college, and the marketing efforts used in media to normalize drinking all weave together to create a hazardous environment where the need to drink (media), meets past behavior (college), and mixes with current trends (high ABVs) to beg the question, what is moderate? 

The Bottom Line

Moderate drinking isn’t impossible and even has some marginal health benefits. However, there are numerous factors that need to be weighed heavily when deciding to drink, such as: how have I historically approached drinks, how do I view media that promotes alcohol (favorably?), and what type of alcohol do I gravitate towards? The answer to these questions will enable you to determine whether you are likely to drink in moderation; but still, such as the case with rising ABVs, the term “drink responsibly” is also subject to change.

title: Digestive Health: Fiber
body:
According to the Health Services department at Cornell University (Gannet), “The most immediate benefit of dietary fiber is its improvement of digestive function.” This article will examine fiber’s role in digestion with particular emphasis on how it affects the colon.

What is Dietary Fiber?

According to Gannet, “Dietary fiber is the edible component of plant foods that can’t be digested by humans.” While it doesn’t provide any nutritional value, dietary fiber aids digestion by improving the absorption of nutrients, the presence of intestinal bacteria, and the colon’s motility (moving indigestible material to the rectum). There are two types of dietary fiber: soluble (able to be dissolved in water) and insoluble fiber. According to Medline Plus, soluble fiber dissolves into a gel substance when it reaches the colon. This process occurs through colonic fermentation—whereby bacteria in the colon interact with ingested material in order to produce gases and short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), which have numerous health benefits including controlling blood glucose (sugar) levels and improving intestinal immune function. Insoluble fiber doesn’t dissolve in water, but rather attracts and absorbs it. This serves to add bulk to your diet as it makes you feel full, improve the consistency of stool through hydration, and increases bowel movements by engaging colonic motility. Soluble fiber is found in “oat bran, barley, nuts, seeds, beans, lentils, peas, and some fruits and vegetables,” whereas insoluble is found in “wheat bran, vegetables, and whole grains.”

Utilizing Dietary Fiber for Improved Health

Adding fiber to your diet is one of the best ways to improve your digestive health, especially if you suffer from constipation or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Constipation is a result of infrequent bowel movements (typically less than 3 times a week) which tend to produce hard and dry stool. Insoluble fiber addresses these issues as it absorbs water in the colon during digestion and both softens and moistens stool. In addition, the consistency of this stool is able to be easily moved to the rectum by the colon, increasing bowel movement. IBS typically includes abdominal pain and irregular bowel movements. While treatment outside of diet (e.g., being prescribed probiotics and going to stress management) aid in treating this complex disease, adding fiber is still one of the quickest and most effective solutions to controlling symptoms. As mentioned previously, fiber increases regularity constipation and improves consistency which relieves constipation and diarrhea respectively. As there is no single treatment for IBS—and particularly the pain associated with it—prevention is the best form of medicine. Sticking to a healthy diet with plenty of fiber, along with performing exercise and other healthy behaviors, is the best way to combat this disease.

Dietary Fiber Recommendations

While fiber is important for digestive health, too much of it can cause symptoms that typically result from poor digestive health; e.g., gas, bloating, and abdominal pain. According to Medline Plus, “The average American now eats 10 to 15 grams of fiber per day. The recommendation for older children, adolescents, and adults is to eat 20 to 35 grams of fiber each day.”

The Bottom Line

As the average American doesn’t get enough fiber in their diet it is likely beneficial that the inclusion of additional fiber will aid in digestive health. Both types of fiber (soluble and insoluble) are necessary for the proper maintenance of the colon and to prevent issues that stem from poor colonic health (e.g., constipation, diarrhea, etc). Whole grains, nuts and seeds, and fruits and vegetables are excellent sources of fiber and should always be added to your diet.
