title: Digestive Health: Disorders
body:
When it comes to peace of mind, your gut is largely influential. In fact, a 2008 paper titled, “Brain foods: the effects of nutrients on brain function,” goes into detail on how the nutrients of food impact the enzymes of the gut, which consequently interact with neurons in the brain. But even though food has a real affect on mood (and brain function for that matter), many Americans suffer from digestive disorders. The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) remarks that “60 to 70 million people are affected by all digestive diseases’—almost a quarter of the population. Digestive disorders impact the processing of nutrients and bring on discomfort. Some of the most common are chronic constipation, acid reflux, gallstones and irritable bowel syndrome. This article will examine these disorders and setup one’s diet as the main determinant to good (or bad) digestive health.

Chronic Constipation

One of the worst feelings is being backed up, and unfortunately many Americans face this scenario on a daily basis. According to the NIDDK constipation “is the most common gastrointestinal complaint in the United States” accounting for 2 million annual doctor visits and $725 million spent annually on laxatives. Constipation is described as infrequent (less than three times a week) bowel movements which are hard and dry in appearance and texture. For comparison, many individuals move their bowels one to three times a day. Constipation occurs when the large intestines, responsible for absorbing fluid and nutrients of food before it moves to the rectum, absorbs too much fluid leaving a hardened stool. These stools are difficult to pass and result in infrequent bowel movements. While typically seen as more of an annoyance than anything, constipation (when chronic) can lead to problems that can become severe. Hemorrhoids (swollen or inflamed veins in the anal canal), anal fissures (a skin break or tear in the anal canal), and fecal impaction (hard stool packed in the intestine and rectum over time) are complications that can result from constipation. The causes of constipation are varied, but the most common are: not enough fiber in the diet, not enough liquids in the diet, pregnancy, lack of exercise, stress, and ironically the overuse of laxatives.

Acid Reflux

For those who’ve ever had heartburn, the thought of getting it again is enough to throw off one’s appetite. Heartburn is caused by acid reflux, a situation where the lower esophageal sphincter (the circular group of muscles that control what goes into the stomach from the esophagus) either doesn’t close all the way after allowing food to pass or opens to frequently. This allows stomach acid to enter the esophagus and creates a burning sensation. Individuals who have frequent heartburn, typically twice or more a week should see a doctor as they may have gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). According to NIDDK, some common symptoms of GERD is: “bad breath, nausea, pain in your chest or the upper part of your abdomen, problems swallowing or painful swallowing, respiratory problems, vomiting, the wearing away of your teeth”. If left untreated, GERD can cause complications such as esophagitis (damaged tissue lining the esophagus leading to bleeding and ulcers), difficulty swallowing, respiratory problems, and Barret’s esophagus (a condition where esophagus tissue is replaced by tissue resembling that found in the intestine). Unchecked cases of esophagitis and Barret’s esophagus can lead to cancer. Treating reflux involves lifestyle changes, medications, or surgery if necessary. Lifestyle changes involve abstaining from smoking, drinking alcohol, and eating greasy, spicy foods. Medications typically involve ingesting an antacid. Surgery is usually an extreme case and typically involves the individual suffering from some physical abnormality that allows GERD to persist.

Gallstones

Like kidney stones, gallstones are hardened material that can become trapped in troublesome places. The gall bladder contains the secreted bile from the liver before it is used in the small intestines. The bile gets to the small intestine via the biliary tract. If a gallstone (or stones) gets trapped in the biliary tract it can sudden and shooting pain in the abdomen, known as a gallbladder attack. Gallstones can be really small or quite large (about the size of a golf ball). Also, there can be many gallstones present in the gallbladder at one time, each of which can vary in size. According to womenshealth.gov these stones are formed when there is an excess of cholesterol in the liquid bile or if the gallbladder doesn’t empty entirely or not enough. Risk factors for gallstones include: having a family history of gallstones, being overweight or obese, consuming a energy-rich, nutrient-poor diet, losing a lot of weight very quickly, being older than 60, have diabetes, or are American Indian or Mexican American. If a gallstone gets trapped in one of the bile ducts it can eventually cause severe damage to the biliary tract, the gallbladder, and the liver. Gallstones can even become fatal in this manner. Fortunately, individuals can reduce their risk for gallstones by eating a low-cholesterol diet, maintaining a healthy weight, and staying active.

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)

IBS is a common yet mysterious disease: it affects approximately 10 to 15 percent of the US population yet doesn’t have a known cause, and diagnosis is based on a pattern of common digestion issues such as abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation—meaning it can easily be mistaken for something else. According to the NIDDK, this disease is classified into four types: 1) IBS with constipation (IBS-C), IBS with diarrhea (IBS-D), Mixed IBS (IBS-M), and Unsubtyped IBS (IBS-U). These distinctions are determined by stool sample and will affect the type of treatment advice from doctors. Symptoms of IBS are typically abdominal pain and a change in bowel movement frequency. While these symptoms are minor, their triggers are many, such as: motility problems in the colon, consuming certain foods, and feelings of stress stemming from depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, and panic disorder can all trigger IBS symptoms. Treatment of IBS typically involves changes to one’s diet and going after the physical symptoms the person experiences—such as taking fiber supplements for constipation, antidepressants for stress, and antispasmodics to control motility.

The Bottom Line

Digestive disorders are common and share similarities in both symptoms and treatment. If you are having trouble going or are experiencing inexplicable abdominal pain then you should schedule a visit with your doctor if these conditions persist. Usually they will recommend a change in diet. Of course, prevention is always better than treatment, so in the next entry in the “Digestive Health” series we will look at how diet affects the digestion system, for better or for worse.

title: Maintaining Health While Healthy Part 5: Food and Mood
body:
When it comes to food and mood, you are what you eat. We tend to soothe ourselves with foods that contain high levels of added fat, sodium, and/or sugar—among other things—when we’re feeling strained. In fact, our current mood is an often overlooked component of our health. In order to maintain one’s health, individuals should understand the relationship food has on their mood.

How Food affects the Brain

It is common knowledge that foods have a basic, physical effect on the body; for example, if you eat too much junk food then you will get fat, or if you don’t eat for a few days you will feel weak. But foods also play a significant role in brain function and by extension one’s mood. A 2008 paper titled, “Brain foods: the effects of nutrients on brain function,” published in Nature Reviews Neuroscience finds that hormones found in the stomach, specifically leptin, ghrelin, glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP1), insulin, and nutrients found in foods have been shown to influence cognition and emotion. According to the paper, leptin is the hunger hormone that reduces one’s appetite (i.e. tells you when you are full) and “facilitates synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus,” which is responsible in strengthening our ability to learn and memorize new information. Ghrelin is a peptide hormone released from the stomach that raises one’s appetite and produces similar benefits as leptin. GLP1 regulates one’s metabolism and improves memory. Insulin is an essential hormone that is produced before, during, and after a meal and affects cognition. In addition, omega-3 fatty acids and micro-nutrients such as iron, zinc, folate, and vitamins A through E were shown to affect “neural pathways that are associated with synaptic plasticity.” These findings present a biological connection between food and the brain, and the necessity of providing the brain with the right kinds of food. When it comes to eating, the hormones in the stomach work with the brain in order to regulate when we eat and stop eating when we feel full. But many foods eaten today (i.e. refined, processed, and packaged foods) can actually make you feel hungry (i.e. not full) cause insulin levels to spike. In an article titled “ 11 foods that make you hungrier,” the author lists many commonly consumed foods that studies show cause hunger by reducing leptin and spiking insulin. As the hormones in the stomach affect learning and memory, foods that constantly make us feel hungry or give us a quick boost of energy (all while lacking essential nutrients) eventually influence our brains into seeing them in an overwhelmingly positive light. When a food tastes bad or makes us feel sick, we begin to form negative associations with that food. This is a basic biological function that has helped people stay away from consuming things that were harmful to them, such as poison which can also be found in certain kinds of berries and mushrooms. But when a food tastes good and makes us feel energetic , we form positive associations. These foods taste good and make us feel energetic. And in the case of foods that reduces leptin production and spikes insulin levels, hormones shown to affect learning and memory, the positive association gets promoted to borderline addiction. Refined, packaged, and processed foods cause cravings, anticipation, highs, and then lows—an emotional roller coaster.

The Bottom Line

The “Brain foods” paper concludes that: “Brain networks that are associated with the control of feeding are intimately associated with those that are involved in processing emotions, reward and cognition.” What this means is that food affects your brain on a neurological level. Healthy foods form positive associations that lead to better health and peace of mind. Refined, packaged, and processed foods form positive associations that lead to cravings and emotional mood swings, typically compounded by the fact that these foods also lead to obesity and other issues. Don’t reward good behavior with junk, and don’t allow negative feedback to occur if you’ve cheated on your diet. The consequences of these actions are more significant than just feeling bad.

title: Maintaining Health While Healthy Part 4: Nutrition Facts Label and Ingredients List
body:
Foods that are refined, processed, and/or packaged – whether organic or non-organic – often contain high levels of added sodium/salt, saturated fat, dietary cholesterol, added sugars/caloric sweeteners, added fats/oils, refined flours/grains, and/or hydrogenated/Trans fats. As your diet is critical in maintaining your health, knowing how to read the Nutrition Facts Label and the Ingredients List on food items is necessary in understanding exactly what you’re putting into your body. This article will examine these two items and can help you to make better food decisions.

What is the Nutrition Facts Label?

Commonly found on the back of packaged food items, the Nutrition Facts Label displays pertinent nutritional information about a particular food product (See Figure 1). In 1990, the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act made it mandatory that this label appear on food items regulated by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). This label contains key information that empowers individuals to make informed health choices including: the serving size and servings per container, the amount of calories consumed per serving, the amount of nutrients consumed per serving, and the recommended values of certain nutrients based on a 2,000 calorie diet. [caption id="attachment_1659" align="alignright" width="237"] Figure 1: The Nutrition Facts Label as it appears on food. Image sourced from Wikipedia.[/caption] The “Serving Size” and “Servings per Container” values at the top of the label can be used to guide understanding of the other values on the label. For example, if one serving size portion contains 230 calories and 160mg of sodium, then two serving size portions will contain 460 calories and 320mg of sodium. The serving size, per the FDA, is standardized across similar foods and is shown in units such as cups or teaspoons followed by their metric equivalents in grams. The amounts of “Calories” per serving along with the amount of “Calories from Fat” are displayed beneath the servings per container. Both weight gain and loss are commonly associated with caloric intake, making this section of particular importance to many individuals. However, calories are simply energy, and solely managing one’s caloric intake doesn’t lead to lasting health as such an approach does not factor in nutrients. There is a reason that the term “empty calories” exists. Beneath the calories is the “Nutrients” section which lists the values of important nutrients including fat, cholesterol, sodium, carbohydrates, protein, and vitamins. For practical purposes, this section can be split up into two sub-sections: the nutrients that you want to limit and the nutrients that you want to maximize. In essence, foods containing vitamins (examples of which include vitamins A through K, iron, calcium, zinc, and so on) should be consumed in abundance, whereas foods with very little vitamins and/or large amounts of nutrients that are not vitamins (i.e. fat, cholesterol, etc.) should be limited. Lastly, there is the section that includes nutrient intake recommendations based on a 2,000-calorie diet. As you may have noticed in Figure 1, the nutrients present on this list contain those that should be limited.

Reading the List of Ingredients

[caption id="attachment_1660" align="alignright" width="461"] Figure 2: The List of Ingredients highlighted in red. Image sourced from the Boston Public Health Commission.[/caption] While the Nutrition Facts Label goes a long way in making healthy food choices, it is only half of the picture. It is also important to know the ingredients that were used in making the food. The Ingredients List is normally found near the Nutrition Facts Label for convenience (See Figure 2). According to the American Heart Association, there are two things to consider when reading the Ingredients List: The “ingredients are listed in order of quantity.” This means that the first few ingredients listed will be the ones that are primarily incorporated into the food. For example, in Figure 2 above, water, black beans, tomatoes, tomato paste, corn, and red bell pepper are the primary ingredients of the food product (in descending order), with the rest of the ingredients making up less than two percent of the food. While the ingredients list displayed in Figure 2 is easy to read and understand, many other products aren’t so…digestible (See Figure 3 below). [caption id="attachment_1661" align="aligncenter" width="879"] Figure 3: List of Ingredients in the popular breakfast cereal “Lucky Charms.” Image sourced from Berkeley.[/caption] 2. The “ingredients can go by several names.” As you will notice in Figure 3, the marshmallows have the second largest presence in the food and include several types of added sugar (among other additives). This brings us to the fact that certain ingredients, in this case sugar, can go by different names (i.e. “sugar,” “corn syrup,” and “dextrose”). In fact, many seemingly common ingredients can go by a variety of names. To fully understand what you are consuming, consult materials from the FDA and other sources which help to demystify ingredient names.

The Bottom Line

In order to maintain your health, you must watch what you eat; however, simply choosing organic, sugar-free, or reduced calorie products won’t do the trick. You must know and understand the Nutrition Facts Label as well as the Ingredients List in order to ensure that what you’re putting into your body is: a) healthy and b) suitable for your current dietary needs. When selecting a product from the grocery store, it is recommended that you turn the container over and read the back.

title: Maintaining Health While Healthy Part 3: Organic Foods
body:
In the previous entry of the “Maintaining Health” series, it was established that what you put into your body is the most important factor in maintaining your health. But while reducing or eliminating refined, processed, and/or packaged foods is fundamental advice for cleaning up your diet, sometimes things get lost in translation when it comes time to shop. According to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), the demand for organic produce has exploded from 2005 to 2014 and the trend looks to continue. However, it is important to note that simply eating organic food doesn’t necessarily mean that one’s diet is safer and more nutritious.

What does “USDA Organic” Mean?

According to the USDA itself: “Organic is a labeling term that indicates that the food or other agricultural product has been produced through approved methods. These methods integrate cultural, biological, and mechanical practices that foster cycling of resources, promote ecological balance, and conserve biodiversity. Synthetic fertilizers, sewage sludge, irradiation, and genetic engineering may not be used.” In addition to the above, the National Organic Program of the USDA observes 4 organic distinctions:
  • 100 Percent Organic: In this category, all ingredients and processing aids must be organic, the information panel must identify organic ingredients, and the product may display the USDA organic seal.
  • Organic: In this category, most of the ingredients are organic, but non-organic ingredients specified on a National List may be used as well (up to five percent of food content). Foods that are organic must identify organic ingredients and may display the USDA organic seal.
  • “Made with organic:” This category specifies multi-ingredient products that contain at least 70 percent organic ingredients. The information panel must identify these ingredients, and the product may display up to three organic ingredients or ingredient categories on the front; the USDA organic seal may not be used.
  • Specific organic ingredients: This category specifies multi-ingredient products with less than 70 percent of its ingredients being organic. These products may only list its organic ingredients on the back as such and may not display the USDA organic seal.
It should be noted that none of the aforementioned categories require the inclusion of labels for livestock products such as: free-range, cage-free, natural, grass-fed, pasture-raised, humane, and no added hormones.

How Does Organic Food Compare to Non-Organic Food?

Individuals who aren’t familiar with the definition(s) of organic food tend to think that they are paying a premium for food that is safer and more nutritious than non-organic food; however, this is only partially true. According to a study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine, the nutritional content of organic foods was not determined to be significantly more nutritious than non-organic food; but the study goes on to say that the consumption of “organic foods may reduce exposure to pesticide residues and antibiotic-resistant bacteria.” Since the nutritional comparison of organic foods to non-organic foods is mostly a moot point, individuals who are looking to understand why choosing organic foods could be beneficial should look to what forms of pesticides are used on the food. According to the National Pesticide Information Center (NPIC), organic foods have less pesticide residue when compared to their conventionally-grown counter-parts (non-organic food). Additionally, organic products may not use synthetic pesticides. While “organic pesticides vs. synthetic pesticides” is an ongoing debate in need of further research, with some sources remarking upon the harmlessness of both (1, 2), what has been decided is that organic foods contain less pesticide residue.

The Takeaway

Choosing organic foods over non-organic foods won’t have a drastic effect on your health. Organic foods aren’t significantly more nutritious than non-organic foods and may still be refined, processed, and/or packaged—meaning their nutritional content may be reduced. Even with organic foods, the things to look out for remain the same: added sodium/salt, saturated fat, dietary cholesterol, added sugars/caloric sweeteners, added fats/oils, refined flours/grains, and hydrogenated/Trans fats. Individuals are encouraged to take note of these ingredients and their respective amounts as indicated on the Nutrition Label. By making decisions based on nutritional content rather than focusing too heavily on organic vs. non-organic, you can ensure that your diet is healthy and nutritious.

Individuals with specific complaints should seek immediate consultation from their personal physicians. It should be noted that none of the aforementioned categories require the inclusion of labels for livestock products such as: free-range, cage-free, natural, grass-fed, pasture-raised, humane, and no added hormones.

title: Maintaining Health While Healthy Part 2: Food
body:
This second “Maintaining Health…” blog is all about what we consume and understanding the value of our diets. By developing a deeper understanding of the role of food in our lives, we will be better prepared to make decisions that benefit our health.

Making Your Diet Trend Towards Healthy

In part 1, it was stated that a healthy diet places emphasis on “reducing and/or eliminating the intake of refined, processed, and packaged foods and moving toward an unrefined, unprocessed plant–based diet that is centered on fruits, vegetables, starchy vegetables, intact whole grains and legumes.” If one were to take a closer look at the quote, “reducing and/or eliminating the intake of refined, processed, and packaged foods” is really the key element as these are the foods that undermine our health, providing little-to-no nutritional value while contributing excessive calories to the diet.

Refined Grains and Added Sugar

There are two types of grains: whole grains and refined grains. According to choosemyplate.gov, “Whole grains contain the entire grain kernel ― the bran, germ, and endosperm. Examples of whole grains include whole-wheat flour, bulgur (cracked wheat), oatmeal, whole cornmeal, and brown rice. Refined grains have been milled, a process that removes the bran and germ. This is done to give grains a finer texture and improve their shelf life, but it also removes dietary fiber, iron, and many B vitamins. Some examples of refined grain products are white flour, de-germed cornmeal, white bread, and white rice.” When we consume a refined grain, we are consuming calories without obtaining as many nutrients with all the benefits of the whole grain. Studies show that consumption of whole grains can help to protect individuals from developing many chronic diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. People who regularly consume whole grains also tend to have lower cholesterol levels and are less prone to obesity. Whole grain snacks include low–fat whole–grain crackers, breads, pretzels and cereals. To snack the right way, individuals should look for food items that are labeled "100% whole grain" and are low in salt, sugar and fat. Added sugar is another major problem in the common American diet, equally as insidious as refined grains but potentially more harmful. According to the American Heart Association (AHA), added sugar can be found in: “soft drinks, sugars, candy, cakes, cookies, pies and fruit drinks (fruitades and fruit punch); dairy desserts and milk products (ice cream, sweetened yogurt and sweetened milk); and other grains (cinnamon toast and honey-nut waffles).” Additionally, added sugar goes by many names on a food’s nutrition label, such as: “brown sugar, corn sweetener, corn syrup, fruit juice concentrates, high-fructose corn syrup, honey, invert sugar, malt sugar, molasses, raw sugar, sugar, sugar molecules ending in “ose” (dextrose, fructose, glucose, lactose, maltose, sucrose), and syrup.” There is naturally-occurring sugar found in fruits (which is made up of both glucose and ‘fructose’) and milk (where the sugar is made up of ‘lactose’). While the chemical structures of naturally–occurring sugars and added sugars are identical, there is an important difference. According to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, 2010, whole foods that naturally contain sugars also naturally contain vitamins, minerals, fiber, water, and other essential nutrients — all of which contribute to "diluting" the concentration of sugar in the food. These foods and beverages include vegetables, fruits, whole grains, dairy products, beans, peas, nuts, and seeds that are prepared without added sugars, starches, solid fats, and sodium. These foods are high in nutrients (nutrient–dense) and low in calories. Foods and beverages that contain excessive amounts of added sugar, on the other hand, are not as nutritionally beneficial. Where there is added sugar, there are more calories but not more nutritional value. Items with added sugars are thus energy–dense and nutrient–poor — the overall calorie density of the food increases while the overall nutrient density decreases. According to the Guidelines and a recent study, added sugar accounts for between 10 and 16 percent of the total calories in the average American diet. This number is far too high, especially when considering that for most individuals to meet their nutritional needs while staying within their calorie limits, the maximum percentage of calories from added sugar should not exceed 5 to 10 percent of total calories.

Processed Foods

Foods that are processed have been altered in some way to aid in consumption or distribution; and while this isn’t inherently bad, according the National Health Service (NHS), these foods may (and typically) contain added salt, sugar, and fat. While it is possible to consume these items in moderation, the problem is that so many foods are processed that it is very easy for people to exceed the recommended limits of salt, sugar, and fat.

Packaged Foods

These foods are, as the name implies, packaged for convenience. They are similar to processed foods in that most packaged foods are altered in some way for distribution. And like processed foods, packaged foods aren’t inherently bad if your diet is low in added salt, sugars, and fats, or if the packaged food is simply whole food chopped and organized to fit in a box. However, packaged foods are listed in this article as many of them go the processed route and are modified with additives. But seeing as many foods need to be packaged, here is a list of healthy packaged foods. The idea is to find those that are least-processed and have minimal amounts of additives.

The Value of a Nutritious Diet

More than any other component, what we put inside our bodies determines the trajectory of our health. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the most common health risk behaviors for chronic illnesses are: “lack of exercise or physical activity, poor nutrition, tobacco use, and and drinking too much alcohol.” As one may observe, three out of the four health risk behaviors involve things that enter the body. Now, abstaining from tobacco and limiting alcohol, while hard for some who’ve developed a habit, are pretty straightforward. Also, getting off the couch and walking around the block isn’t something that requires planning or foresight. Eating, on the other hand, is something that has to take place multiple times a day for survival, which leads to the crux of the health issue: while everybody must eat, individuals must be knowledgeable about their food choices in order to eat healthy.

title: Maintaining Health While Healthy Part 1: Getting There
body:
Over a series of blog posts, we’re going to explore a relatively overlooked topic: how does one maintain health once initial health goals are met? As the saying goes, getting to the top (becoming healthy) can ultimately be the easy part when all is said and done; staying on top (maintaining one’s health for life) is the hard part. Before we worry about staying at the top, however, let’s get there first. Let’s start by becoming un-unhealthy! It’s no secret that America faces a health problem; the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that: “During 2009–2010, approximately 17% of children and adolescents and 36% of adults were obese.” The causes of this health problem are known: “Poor diet and physical inactivity contribute to many serious and costly health conditions, including obesity, heart disease, diabetes, some cancers, unhealthy cholesterol levels, and high blood pressure.” And since a poor diet and physical inactivity are the root causes of general health problems, it would follow that a healthy diet and physical activity are the solutions. In regard to a healthy diet, EHE International’s diet and nutrition expert Jeff Novick recommends: “A well–balanced diet with emphasis on reducing and/or eliminating the intake of refined, processed, and packaged foods and moving toward an unrefined, unprocessed plant–based diet that is centered on fruits, vegetables, starchy vegetables, intact whole grains and legumes.” In regard to physical activity, the CDC recommends: “2 hours and 30 minutes (150 minutes) of moderate-intensity aerobic activity (i.e., brisk walking) every week and muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that work all major muscle groups (legs, hips, back, abdomen, chest, shoulders, and arms).” Preparing for the Road Ahead It would be easy to follow the above guidelines in an ideal scenario, but the real world is less accommodating, so before you get started there is one thing that you need to know: becoming and remaining healthy is like becoming and remaining wealthy, it’s all about consistency. If you want to stay healthy then you must commit to it absolutely. (Stay Tuned for Part 2)

title: Health-Related Physical Fitness
body:
The Journal of American Medicine reports that more than one-third (approximately 79 million) U.S. adults are obese. Obesity has been shown to be a significant risk factor for “heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes and certain types of cancer.” The kicker is that these obesity-related conditions are the leading causes of preventable death. Yes, preventable death. Fortunately, these issues can be resolved by becoming and/or staying physically fit. While people usually subscribe to the notion that physical fitness is for athletes and models, this article will present physical fitness as a preventive healthcare measure for everyone.

What is “Health-Related Physical Fitness?”

Getting active and ‘in-shape’ as a means to maintain one’s good health is termed “health-related physical fitness,” and the American College of Sports Medicine’s Guidelines for Exercise Testing and Prescription defines it as:
  • “A state characterized by (a) an ability to perform daily activities with vigor, and (b) a demonstration of traits and capacities that are associated with low risk of premature development of hypokinetic diseases (i.e., those associated with physical inactivity.” (pg. 57)
The “traits and capacities” mentioned are the components that determine health-related physical fitness. These include body composition, cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength and endurance, and flexibility.

The Components of Health-Related Physical Fitness

To better understand the importance of increasing your physical fitness, you must first understand the physical fitness components listed above. Body composition: One’s body is naturally designed in a certain way. Some people are tall and others short, some people are bulky and others svelte. For this reason, body composition — the ratio of bodyweight made up of fat to that made up of fat-free tissue — is the preferred way to distinguish whether one is in a good place in regard to weight. Having a high ratio of fat to non-fat is detrimental to your health. Cardiorespiratory endurance: This component is the one that most individuals associate with physical fitness as it involves many muscles in the body, is typically moderate-to-high intensity, and includes dynamic movements — all while being performed for extended periods of time. The standard method of determining cardiorespiratory endurance is measuring one’s maximal oxygen uptake (or rate of oxygen consumption) during exercise (typically cardiovascular exercise). The Guidelines for Exercise and Testing Prescription states that:
  • “… (a) low levels of cardiorespiratory fitness have been associated with markedly increased risk of premature death from all causes and specifically from cardiovascular disease, (b) increases in cardiorespiratory fitness are associated with a reduction in death from all causes, and (c) high levels of cardiorespiratory fitness are associated with higher levels of habitual physical activity, which are, in turn, associated with many health benefits.” (pg. 68)
Muscular strength and endurance: When it comes to the muscles in your body, strength and endurance are the categories that will determine your physical fitness. ‘Muscular strength’ involves the amount of force that a muscle can generate in a given time, and ‘muscular endurance’ refers to the number of times a muscle can be used (contracted) without exhausting. As with cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength and endurance has numerous health benefits including: increasing your metabolism, reducing the ratio of fat to fat-free tissue in the body, and increasing bone mass. Flexibility: One of the more overlooked components of physical fitness, flexibility determines your range of motion. Being able to move without unnecessary encumbrance is key to physical fitness as it will determine your fitness ceiling. Inflexible people are unable to recruit their joints and muscles efficiently, and are thus limited in the exercises that they can perform. Put another way, inflexibility in a situation that might require greater range of motion (such as exercise) can cause tissue damage as the joints and muscles are pushed pass their limits.

Tips and Exercises to Increase Health-Related Physical Fitness

Now that we understand the importance of being physically fit along with the components of fitness, it is time to act on this knowledge. But first, here are some important guidelines to remember from EHE International Health Coach Gayle Salomon:
  • Focus on you; don’t make comparisons with others unless it is used for motivation.
  • Physical fitness is about movement and activity. Try an exercise and see if you can do it; worry about performance later.
  • When just starting, remember to take it slow—progression is the aim.
  • Once you’ve become comfortable doing certain exercises/running certain distances, look to gradually increase the workload.
  • Age is a big factor in progression: the older you are, the more time it will take and the more care you should give to your fitness regimen.
  • When you start getting comfortable, you can switch up your routine by adding or targeting different muscle groups; just try something totally new so that you can keep improving.
  • Observe what you are doing so that progression may take place. Monitor your heart rate, count your steps, and time your runs. Take your exercise routine seriously by tracking your progress.
By adhering to these simple guidelines, you will have a safe and healthy mentality when looking to increase your physical fitness.

Exercises

Body composition: Becoming physically fit will naturally help your body composition, so there aren’t specific exercises for body composition. Cardiorespiratory endurance: Some effective exercises are: walking, jogging, running, sprinting, interval training, bicycling, and swimming. Remember to start out slow; look to increase your workload as you feel more comfortable. Muscular strength and endurance: Effective exercises include push-ups, sit-ups, squats, lunges, and calf-raises. For muscular strength, you should look to perform these movements with added weight; for muscular endurance, you should look to practice timed tests in which you perform as many repetitions as you can, without sacrificing form. Beginners should first get used to the movements and then look to improve. More advanced individuals should look to increase resistance for strength and increase time, repetitions, or both for endurance. Flexibility training: These exercises should be performed every day, ideally twice a day — 5 minutes in the morning and 5 minutes before going to bed. Flexibility training is similar to muscular training in that it is specific to target location (i.e., if you stretch your legs, your shoulders won’t necessarily increase in flexibility). Some effective exercises are: hamstring and quadriceps stretching (standing, sitting, or lying down), spinal twists, knees-to-chest, back extensions, forward and side lunges, shoulder stretches, and neck stretches. Beginners and advanced individuals should go as far as they can until they feel slightly uncomfortable — but not to the point of pain — and look to stretch, lunge, etc. a little further each time.

The Takeaway

Becoming physically fit is a mindset as much as it is a performance. By understanding the benefits of being physically fit and the types of exercise that will help you achieve your goals, you can embark on a journey toward a healthier life.

title: Core Muscles
body:
Over the past decade, the word “core” has become a very popular buzzword within the fitness community. There are many fitness product commercials and websites that equate the strengthening of one’s core to improved athletic performance. However, like many health-related topics, the true importance of the core is hidden underneath a commonly held misconception: that strengthening the core leads to improved performance. In actuality, the main benefit of a strong core is injury prevention.

What are the Core Muscles?

The muscles and tendons that make up an individual’s core include the rectus abdominis, transversus abdominis, internal and external obliques, erector spinae, multifidus, the pelvic floor, and the diaphragm; essentially, the core includes everything except for the limbs and appendages. The muscles of the core work to support, stiffen, and stabilize the spine, abdomen, and pelvis; distributing and generating force without placing undo stress on the joints.

Core Stability, Athletic Performance, and Injury Prevention

A core-strengthening program increases core stability, which is the capacity of the body to return to equilibrium (or balance) after being in a state of non-equilibrium. Activities that attempt to throw off the body’s equilibrium can generally be called “functional movements.” Participating in sports, riding the subway, and even getting up from a chair are functional movements as the body is constantly re-aligning its center of gravity to effectively handle force distribution. Functional training, or training for specific movements, has become popular among athletes and fitness enthusiasts alike. The thinking is that if you train your body to effectively transfer force with movements that mimic those that would occur in a real-life scenario (like throwing a medicine ball to mimic passing a basketball), your body will adapt to these movements and be able to execute them better. This is the basis for the argument that core strength equals improved performance, and it is easy to make this argument when individuals are incorporating a total body workout in addition to core strengthening. Study after study has concluded, however, that functional training and core strengthening alone do not increase performance. You might be wondering then, “if this stuff doesn’t make me jump higher or run faster then what’s the point?” The point is preventive healthcare. While most studies attempting to link core strength and athletic performance have been met with underwhelming results, there is a wealth of literature espousing the link between core strength and injury prevention. The article “Core Stability Exercise Principles (2008),” remarks that individuals with lower back pain (LBP) have “delayed contraction of the transversus abdominis and multifidi prior to limb movement.” Additionally, the document notes that “people with sacroiliac pain have impaired recruitment of the diaphragm and pelvic floor.” This shows that individuals with weak cores are susceptible to these and other musculoskeletal injuries. Another study showed that in the dangerous world of firefighting, an occupation that requires extensive functional movements in less than ideal situations, injuries were reduced significantly when the firefighters were placed under a core strengthening program: “Comparing the number of injuries pre- and post- intervention of these 433 firefighters, loss time injuries were reduced by 62%, whereas total injuries were reduced by 44% compared to a historical group.” This is significant because, according to article, “injuries are the leading cause of mortality and loss of potential years of life for working individuals.”

The Takeaway

By only strengthening your core, you won’t become a better athlete because the core efficiently distributes force rather than generating it. What you will accomplish, however, is even more important. You will improve your body’s ability to maintain equilibrium, protect against injury and various health conditions related to the muscles and joints, and increase your functional independence.  So, while it may not improve your performance on the basketball court, functional training can increase the strength of the muscles that provide stability and mobility for the spine, pelvis, rib cage, and hips.

title: Snow Removal Safety
body:
From the novelty of the season’s first storm to the seemingly endless onslaught of recent weeks, snow has been a looming presence in the lives of many Americans this winter. Of course, snow does have its perks. It is enjoyable to look at, ski on top of, sled through, and roll into snowmen and snowwomen. What is much less enjoyable is the fact that snow needs to be removed – from roads, driveways, sidewalks, stairs, and walkways. And, while snow removal is almost always a nuisance, it can also be very dangerous if performed incorrectly or without proper precaution. Here are some preventive health tips to keep in mind the next time you head outside to grab your shovel or start your snow blower: Overall Health – Snow removal injuries can range from aches and muscle pulls to fatal heart attacks. If you have a medical condition or do not exercise regularly, it is important to consult a physician before shoveling or snow blowing.   It may not be a bad idea to hire someone to complete the work. Clothing – According to the CDC, you should dress in several layers of loose-fitting wool, silk, or polypropylene clothing; wear a hat, mittens, and a scarf or mask that covers the face and mouth; and wear a tightly-woven, wind and water-resistant coat and water-resistant boots.  Additionally, go indoors if persistent shivering occurs. Shivering should not be ignored as it is an important first sign that the body is losing heat. Sun Safety – According to the Skin Cancer Foundation (SCF), “snow reflects up to 80 percent of the UV light from the sun, meaning that you are often hit by the same rays twice.” Apply a broad–spectrum, water–resistant sunscreen of at least SPF 30 to all exposed areas 30 minutes before going outdoors. Reapply every two hours or as needed. You can protect your eyes and vision by wearing goggles or sunglasses that block 99 to 100 percent of both UVA and UVB rays. Snow Removal Technique –The American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) recommends the following precautions:
  • Warm up muscles (especially the back, arm and leg muscles) by stretching for at least ten minutes before beginning snow removal.
  • Use a shovel that is appropriate for your height and strength.
  • Hold the shovel close to the body and always try to push rather than lift the snow. If lifting the snow cannot be avoided, it is important to do it properly by squatting with feet apart and lifting with the legs while keeping the back straight.
  • Lift only small amounts of snow at one time. Snow should never be thrown over the shoulder or to the side as those motions require twisting of the back and can lead to injury.
  • Remove snow early and often during a snowstorm when the snow is light and powdery.
  • Read instructions and carefully follow precautions listed in the operations manual when using a snow blower.
  • Never stick hands in a snow blower. If snow becomes too impacted, stop the engine and wait at least five seconds before using a solid object to clear wet snow or debris from the chute.
  • Take frequent breaks and drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration. For both men and women, the most common sign of a heart attack is chest pain, pressure, or discomfort. Anyone who experiences these or other symptoms of a heart attack should stop and seek emergency care immediately.
So, the next time you head outdoors to remove snow, do it safely - take some extra time and heed the recommendations listed above.

title: Health Benefits of Exercise Is a Fountain of Youth
body:
Looking and feeling young and fit seems to be a top priority in the U.S., as Americans dole out over $12 billion for cosmetic surgeries in a year, and the average woman will spend $15,000 on make-up in her life time. Looking healthy and vital, however, is not something that we have to buy. Regular exercise, a healthy diet, and proper medical care are the best ways to slow the aging process. Living well is its own proverbial fountain of youth.

Oxygen: Can’t Live With It and Can't Live Without It

In the 1950s, Dr. Denham Harman developed the scientific understanding of “free radicals” as the cause of aging. Basically, “the theory says a byproduct of oxygen use is adverse chemical reactions in cells. The result is aging and, ultimately, death.” We can slow the production of free radicals by staying fit and eating right. We can also limit the production of new free radicals by avoiding excessive smoking and drinking. However, aging is not something that can be stopped altogether. It is a natural process of living organisms.

Active Equals Younger

Although aging is not fully understood by science, a new study published in the Journal of Physiology is adding to the growing body of knowledge regarding the role of fitness in the aging process. Researchers evaluated older adults who were avid cyclists compared to a sedentary group. “Active older people resemble much younger people physiologically,” writes the New York Times’ Gretchen Reynolds. “The findings suggest that many of our expectations about the inevitability of physical decline with advancing years may be incorrect and that how we age is, to a large degree, up to us.” Medical science has long understood the health benefits of exercise in preventing bone and muscle loss, especially in older adults. Further medical research has examined the ability of regular exercise to “beneficially affect and retard biological aging.” The evidence points to consistent exercise as the most effective tool for remaining youthful and preventing the onset of aging (as much as biologically possible). "If you had to pick one thing, one single thing that came closest to the fountain of youth," says James Fries, M.D., a pioneer researcher on healthy aging at Stanford University in an AARP article, "then it would have to be exercise." There are certain exercises you can do to help resist aging. As with any new fitness routine, seek advice from your physician first. Until the fountain of youth is discovered, we have the tools for staying young in our own hands by simply exercising and living a healthy lifestyle. Ponce de Leon is not required.

title: Fitness Programs Are Critical to Employee Wellness
body:
Employee wellness programs are increasingly popular in corporate America. A National Business Group on Health survey shows that spending on employee wellness programming increased by 15 percent in 2013 from the previous year, and the number of companies offering incentives for participation in such programs "has increased from 57 percent in 2009 to 74 percent in 2014." These trends include growth in subsidized gym memberships and exercise programs. A focus on fitness makes sense for all involved. Companies reap tax benefits from fitness programs, and employees enjoy improved health outcomes by participating. A healthy workforce may also result in further savings for companies through lower healthcare costs. A 2012 U.S. Department of Labor-commissioned study reports that "30 percent of all employers and 63 percent of large firms provided either gym membership discounts or on-site exercise facilities" for employees. However, corporate incentives alone may be enough to get some everyone to the gym. Many people struggle with motivation, scheduling, and knowing how to integrate exercise in their daily routine. The success of these fitness programs are defined by the employees who must take advantage of these benefits. One person’s motivation to go to the gym regularly is different from another.

Let’s Get Physical

Starting a physical activity regimen is easier with a gym membership. A gym's operating hours allow for a consistent exercise schedule regardless of weather, and a variety of equipment and activities help prevent boredom. If you have a membership, begin by planning workout times around your daily schedule. Develop your exercise plan based upon the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans. In order to obtain health benefits, the Guidelines recommend adults perform the following:
  • 2 hours and 30 minutes (150 minutes) of moderate-intensity aerobic activity (i.e., brisk walking) every week, plus muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that target all major muscle groups (legs, hips, back, abdomen, chest, shoulders, and arms).
  • OR 1 hour and 15 minutes (75 minutes) of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity (i.e., jogging or running) every week, plus muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that target all major muscle groups (legs, hips, back, abdomen, chest, shoulders, and arms).
  • OR an equivalent mix of moderate- and vigorous-intensity aerobic activity and muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week, plus muscle-strengthening activities on 2 or more days a week that target all major muscle groups (legs, hips, back, abdomen, chest, shoulders, and arms).
As always, talk with a physician before you begin any new exercise program.

When a Gym Card Is Not Enough

Many of us struggle with finding the time and motivation to go to the gym regardless of a company discount and convenient access to a fitness center. It’s easy to make excuses. We convince ourselves we are too busy, too tired, or too bored with the gym. Many of us don’t see immediate results from exercise and give up. These fitness roadblocks can be overcome. The most important thing to do is to just keep active. EHE health coaches recommend:
  • Finding a motivation that works for you
  • Setting realistic goals and push yourself
  • Trying different types of exercises thath fit your lifestyle
  • Changing it up to keep workouts dynamic and engaging
  • Going with a gym partner to help motivate you to put on the sweat pants
  • Joining a group exercise class

It Doesn’t Matter Where You Sweat

If you don’t have a gym membership, there are many ways to be active outside of a spinning class and without an expensive treadmill. The American College of Sports Medicine recommends basic activities you can do almost anywhere:
  • Do flexibility exercises at least two or three days each week at home before or after work
    • Each stretch should be held for 10-30 seconds to the point of tightness or slight discomfort.
  • Start exercises slowly and build time, intensity and frequency
    • Depending on your fitness level and lifestyle, beginning with 5-10 minutes a day and adding small increments each week may be more manageable
  • Perform various physical activities throughout the day for 10-20 minutes each
    • Take a walk after work, lift hand weights in your office during lunch, or walk up the stairs instead of using the elevator/escalator
  • Build light, moderate, or vigorous physical activities into your life every day
    • Stand up and walk around while you talk on the phone
    • Walk to do local errands
    • Do chores the old fashion way, like garden work with a rake instead of leaf blower, use a broom instead of vacuum, and hand wash the car

Except No Substitutions

The science on physical activity as a means to improve your health is well known in the medical field. From preventing serious disease to improving your brain health, exercise is an equal and integral component of healthy living along with proper diet. You can’t have one without the other. Fad diets and unproven trends like a "polypill" should not be relied upon as a quick fix or substitute for a healthy lifestyle (but may be prescribed by physicians when necessary). To improve cardiovascular health and prevent disease, it’s simple: eat right and get moving. There are no alternatives to exercise. Ultimately, it is up to us to make fitness a priority in our lives. "We all know that we should be physically active because it’s good for us, but we may not know how good and in how many different ways it can be particularly beneficial," says EHE Health Coach Shereé Chambers. "Better than a pill or fad diet, being physically active can positively affect your life right now — from boosting your energy and mood, decreasing disease risk, and increasing lifespan, to improving your confidence, work performance, and sex life."

title: Don’t Fear Medical Screenings
body:
As the saying goes, “knowledge is power.” When it comes to personal health, however, many prefer another adage: “ignorance is bliss.” Visiting the doctor for a medical exam and learning one’s overall health status may stir up thoughts of mortality and guilt for not taking better care of our bodies, especially as we age. This avoidance mindset will not help us make pro-active decisions about our health. “Avoiding medical tests because of anxiety can cause more health problems, such as fatigue, muscle tension, restlessness, and difficulty sleeping, according to the Anxiety and Depression Association of America,” writes John Fortunbury in The Atlantic. “Even if the worry is only an occasional one, [anxiety] weakens the immune system.”

A Matter of Perspective

You can turn around fear of seeking and understanding health information by embracing medical screenings and preventive exams as tools to build a plan to get and/or stay healthy. When a doctor conducts a thorough exam and provides the results, you are in command. If you take control over medical information, instead of the other way around, you will not only alleviate anxiety but change your health outcomes. EHE Physician Dr. Gabriella Trotta-Barni says, “knowledge of certain information, such as cholesterol levels or blood pressure can be empowering; with a change in lifestyle habits, like diet and exercise, one can decrease cardiovascular risk, and feel better in general.”

It's Just a Test

In other words, approach medical screenings like taking a test. We all take tests in school to measure where we are and what we’ve learned thus far. A medical screening is no different. There’s no failing grade, and it’s not a prescription for your destiny. Preventive medical screenings are conducted to establish a physical health baseline in order to know what to address and where to make improvements. "When we avoid preventive tests we take away our greatest weapon in fighting chronic disease,” says psychologist Mike Friedman of EHE’s Medical Advisory Board. “We must remember that most diseases are chronic but controllable if we detect them and implement strong health behaviors." Even if medical screenings find a problem, catching it in the early stages may prevent an ailment from becoming a chronic disease and/or make it more manageable. Don’t leave your medical condition unresolved. Far from being scary, a proper medical screening is your greatest protection from harm and the best resource for improving your overall health.

title: Diarrhea: The #1 Traveler's Health Issue
body:
American travelers abroad frequently get sick from eating foods or drinking water because we often have no immunity to local pathogens. If you don’t take certain health precautions, you may eventually pay the consequences. Stomach and digestive problems should not be the price of your visit nor a test of your mettle as a traveler. A night or two spent in a hotel bathroom is no fun, and stomach infections can lead to aggravated health issues, especially for children or individuals with compromised immune systems. “While you can be adventurous in your travels, try not to be so adventurous in your food choices while in third world countries,” says EHE International travel medicine nurse practitioner Marianne Dyke. “Nobody wants digestive distress while away from home.” Diarrhea affects 30% to 70% of travelers and is the most predictable travel-related illness. Your personal health status and travel destination greatly impacts the types of precautions you should take. The exposure potential is relative to the season and destination:
  • Low risk: United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Western Europe
  • Intermediate risk: Eastern Europe, South Africa, Caribbean islands
  • High risk: Asia, Middle East, Africa, Mexico, Central and South America

Traveler’s Health Scourge

Diarrhea is more than inconvenient. Bacteria and viruses may cause severe dehydration and lead to gastrointestinal problems. In extreme cases, infections become acute medical conditions requiring a hospital stay. A doctor may recommend a prophylactic vaccine (such as against Typhoid) if exposure is unavoidable. Traveler’s diarrhea is common, but many of us don’t know what preventive health measures to take and rely on word-of-mouth or unscientific remedies. Follow a few simple steps in your daily routine:
  • Drink only bottled water and beverages
  • Do not eat from street vendors in third world countries
  • Eat well cooked foods or steamed vegetables in restaurants regardless of your location
  • Avoid raw fruit and vegetables
  • Do not use ice in beverages
  • Brush your teeth with bottled water
The best advice for avoiding diarrhea is to talk with a travel medicine doctor. A doctor trained in preventive health for travelers will help plan your itinerary and provide care specific to your needs. With proper information and smart choices, you will not have to worry about diarrhea—and enjoy your travels. Schedule a travel health appointment

title: Preventive Care & the Obesity Crisis
body:
A comprehensive study on America’s growing obesity epidemic has little good news. The research report, State of Obesity, reveals that over 1/3 of Americans are becoming dangerously fatter in every category. The report by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF) and Trust for America’s Health (TFAH) breaks down obesity rates by geography. The population of every state in the union is now over 20% obese, while 20 states top 30%. "This is a problem that doesn't have either a single solution or a single cause," said Jeffrey Levi, Ph.D., executive director of TFAH, reported in the Huffington Post. "But certainly, over the last 30 years, we've seen a dramatic increase in fast food outlets and our lifestyle changes ... in terms of what we're eating, the quality of what we're eating and where we're eating it, and [decreasing] physical activity levels." As Dr. Levi suggests, medical professionals are only beginning to understand the extent of the problem and must grapple with a condition which stretches beyond health issues. How we eat is a complex story.

Inequality of Obesity

News reports have picked up on the obesity report’s illustration of the disparities across population groups. Being extremely overweight in America is directly related to where you live, your racial/ethnic background, and income level.   Reporter Lindsey Cook pinpoints a few notable statistics which makes obesity a higher risk for certain groups: “8 percent of blacks live in a census tract with a supermarket, compared with 31 percent of whites. A whopping 23.5 million of Americans don't live within a mile of a supermarket. This is important because research has shown blacks with a supermarket in their neighborhood consume 32 percent more fruits and vegetables.” With whole communities unable to access grocery stores for nutritious foods, people rely on fat-filled convenience store snacks for their primary meals.

Systemic Malnutrition

Kelly D. Brownell and Katherine Battle Horgen, authors of Food Fight: The Inside Story of the Food Industry, puts the blame squarely on a "toxic food environment” created in modern America. June Stevens sums the basic claims of Food Fight:
“Simply stated, increased food consumption means increased profits—but increased food consumption is not consistent with the health needs of our over-nourished population. The authors expose the role of corporations that sell foods that contribute to the obesity epidemic, but they stop short of painting the food companies as nefarious villains.”
Essentially, industrial food production and distribution makes it difficult for many of us to eat healthy, regardless of our food choices.

Baked in the Genes

Recent British studies have found some infants are born with greater appetites and, thus, a predisposition towards weight gain. "Appetite is key and it would be sensible for parents to keep an eye on children who appear to be responding to food a lot more avidly than their peers," said Clare Llewellyn a researcher at the University College London. "Those who have inherited genes that make them feel less full are more likely to overeat and gain weight." If you don’t have the natural mental and physical triggers to stop eating, you may easily develop eating behaviors that lead to chronic obesity.

Expanding Waistlines & Wallets

Obesity takes an enormous toll on one’s personal health and longevity, medical professionals warn. The financial costs of a heavier and unhealthy American public should not be overlooked:
  • $160 Billion increase in medical expenses
  • $938 Billion increase in fuel costs from passenger weight
  • $7.5 Billion increase in clothing expenses for bigger sizes

What Can You Do?

Obesity has complicated healthcare, environmental, genetic and socio-economic factors. Preventive health measures to address obesity can only go so far given the surrounding thicket of social issues and policy decisions. Reducing excessive weight gain is no longer a simple dinner plate choice. However, this doesn’t mean you should give up on diet and exercise or fall into despair if you are struggling with obesity. You can take a first step by visiting a doctor with expertise in preventive care. By fully assessing your medical condition, a physician will develop a solid nutrition and exercise plan to fit your lifestyle and your goals.

title: Preventive Exams Best Defense Against HPV
body:
The head of the New York City Council has been diagnosed with human papillomavirus (HPV) – a common sexually-transmitted disease that affects both women and men. Serious infections may lead to cancer if not caught early and treated. Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito announced the surprising diagnosis on her Twitter account: Like many of us who live busy lives, the Speaker overlooked her own personal health and skipped regular check-ups with a doctor. Medical experts recommend women receive PAP tests every 3 years beginning at age 21, and be screened for HPV at age 30. Because signs are not always visible, most women who have HPV infections never know it. Visit a gynecologist at least once a year for check-ups regardless of your sexual activity or age, and follow your doctor’s recommendations regarding frequency of HPV screenings. All men and women should be evaluated for HPV vaccination eligibility during preventive health exams or with a primary care physician. Results from studies demonstrate that the HPV vaccine is effective in reducing infections; however, as EHE physician Dr. Seema Sarin notes: “The HPV vaccine is not perfectly protective, meaning that some men and women will acquire an HPV infection despite having being vaccinated. The vaccine does not prevent other sexually-transmitted infections, including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), herpes, chlamydia, and gonorrhea. Thus, it is important to always practice safer sex to reduce the risk of all sexually-transmitted diseases.” Speaker Mark-Viverito, who is 45, plans to use her personal medical struggle to raise awareness about HPV: Some people feel uncomfortable discussing sexually-transmitted diseases and, therefore, do not request medical screenings. "Presumably the stigma of sexually transmitted diseases occurs to discourage unsafe sexual behavior,” says psychologist Dr. Mike Friedman. “But for many it actually discourages testing and responsible preventive behavior. We need to find a way to encourage safe sex without discouraging testing." Melissa Mark-Viverito’s openness about her HPV screening and treatment has already inspired at least one person to be pro-active with her health. Responding to the Speaker’s announcement, a follower was reminded of the importance of regular preventive exams: “I haven't seen a GYN in like 5 years. You just inspired me,” she tweeted. “We need to take care of ourselves so we can take care of others."

title: Robin Williams & Depression’s Health Risk
body:
The apparent suicide of beloved actor and ground-breaking comedian Robin Williams was greeted by a collective national shock. People are understandably distraught over a popular figure dying by his own hand. Robin was a performer bursting with vitality; sadness to the point of suicide didn’t appear to be in his DNA. Although he has opened up about his alcohol and drug addiction over the years, Robin’s manic performance style left audiences with an impression his life was perhaps over-flowing at times but not depressed. Robin Williams’s death is a reminder of our misperceptions about clinical depression and its severity. Depression is the most prominent mental disorder and a major national health risk, affecting nearly 16 million Americans at some point in their lives. “But despite how common the illness is,” reports Karen Rowan of Yahoo News, “many people do not understand exactly what it means to have depression, and often think of it as being the same as sadness.” Mental health professionals define clinical depression as a severe mental state that doesn’t go away with time and places the sufferer’s physical health in danger. Mental illness takes a toll on the body. “Depression is a prevalent and chronic mental disorder causing suffering, loss of function and loss of life,” says psychologist Dr. Mike Friedman, medical advisory board member at EHE International. Dr. Friedman further explains on his Psychology Today blog:
“Depression is associated with reduced heart rate variability, platelet aggregation and increased sympathetic nervous system activity, all of which increase risks for patients with cardiac disease. Further, depressed individuals often have reduced energy and lower motivation, which interferes with activities like exercise, buying and preparing healthy foods, and attending medical appointments, all of which are critical for restoring heart health.” Robin’s death tragically demonstrates the greatest threat. “Suicide is a common symptom of severe, clinical depression,” explains Dr. John M. Grohol on his blog. “When properly treated, the feelings of suicide often remit as the depression lifts. But even under treatment, sometimes people choose to take their own life.” Suicide is the 10th leading cause of death in the U.S., but Robin’s fate is not the inevitable result of depression. Mental illness has warning signs, knowable health risk factors, and available treatment options. "But there are barriers that need to be overcome to adequately address depression," notes Dr. Friedman in a CNN.com op-ed. "First and foremost, the stigma of depression is making us sicker." May the great funnyman’s loss serve to enlighten us about the reality of depression and help us to recognize and treat it early. Resources:
  • National Association of Mental Illness
  • Suicide Prevention Hotline: 1-800-273-8255

title: Evaluating Your Health Risk Is a Conversation
body:
A thorough examination and comprehensive set of preventive health screenings by medical experts will produce valuable data for your doctor; however, health care isn’t all a numbers game. Talk with your doctor to fully understand what the data charts mean in real-life terms to you. This is particularly critical when making medical or lifestyle decisions based on risk factors—whether to change your diet, go on medications, or have major surgery. Prevention is founded upon a dialogue where patients are active partners with doctors in developing their care.

What to Expect from a Risk Assessment

As the CDC advises, only trained doctors should perform examinations and evaluate your health status and risks. Provide your physician with as much information as possible about your current health issues (including any medical conditions or prescriptions), past health problems (even if no longer present), and family members’ health status (e.g., history of diabetes, breast cancer, or heart attacks). Your doctor should be very inquisitive, ask follow-up questions, and request previous medical records if needed. A preventive health risk assessment should include a full physical examination, biometric screenings, blood draw, EKG, and other tests appropriate for your age, gender, and physical condition. A physician needs various types of information to create a complete picture of your physical condition. Based on established preventive health guidelines, this is what a sound examination looks like:

Be a Smart Health Information Consumer

Although you may feel uncomfortable talking about health issues, an open conversation with your doctor will help build a plan to protect your future health. There is no one-size-fits-all way to explain health risk. For instance, some people prefer percentage break downs (e.g., 10% chance of developing colon cancer), but this may not be right for you. Furthermore, a Massachusetts General Hospital study found “only about 20 percent of the physicians said they were very comfortable using numbers and explaining probabilities to patients." Whether your doctor provides numerical specifics or speaks in a broad sense, you should ask questions, bring up concerns, and collaborate with your doctor in making lifestyle changes to lower your health risk.
Prior to a doctor visit, make a list of questions and concerns no matter how insignificant. “Having some sort of written guidance can be very helpful,” notes EHE preventive health physician Dr. Gabriella Trotta-Barni. “Patients may become flustered and feel intimidated once they sit down with a doctor.” Here is a helpful checklist for talking with your doctor. Clear communication is the key to understanding your health risk and taking action.

title: Seeing Through the Smoke: Cigarettes and the Preventive Health Message
body:
CVS, the national pharmacy and convenience retail chain, announced it will no longer sell tobacco products in its 7,600 stores. CVS’s bold announcement (relinquishing nearly $2 billion in sales) may not effect whether someone takes their first puff or their last. Yet, when a national pharmacy and wellness retailer stops selling a product known to cause preventable diseases to its customers, there’s an implicit preventive health message. The health hazards of smoking are well documented (EHE first raised the alarm in 1939), and the benefits of quitting – no matter your age or when you stop – are undeniable. After the first 24 hours of quitting, for instance, a smoker’s chance of a heart attack decreases. But this knowledge doesn’t make quitting any easier. The best way to stop smoking is to never start or quit as early as possible. We all struggle with forecasting risks when we make decisions about our health. Many smokers will tell you this is critical. Recently, Star Trek Actor Leonard Nimoy announced that he is suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) brought on by smoking. Fans became concerned when photographs of him with an oxygen tank surfaced. As Mr. Nimoy soberly demonstrates, prevention is a mind-set we need to get into early. Thinking preventively may help as us navigate the array of health decisions we face every day. Smoking, in particular, is a behavior that can profoundly impact your health later in life.
